Name: Bodhi Spending Planners Pty Ltd
Overview:
See yourself Free of Debt and Bill Worries...

I coach and mentor people in Money Management helping them discover why their spending patterns have stifled their dreams.

By using our online Spending Program you will discover where your money is going, how you can take control, what funds you will need and when, so all your bills are covered in a timely manner and how you can start getting debts under control and paid off, plus plan for future unexpected financial events so they don't become a problem.

You will discover that by using our program, you can start dreaming once again, a holiday, a new car, even how you can get off the rent merry-go-round and buy your own home. It is all possible.

I will work with individuals, families and small businesses both in Australia and Overseas as all will find benefit from what I can offer.

We also work with Mortage Brokers by helping their clients organis their spending so they can afford a Mortgage and we will supply the Broker with a 12 month spending analysis to support their duty of care requirements.

So if you are struggling to get on top of Money issues, get in touch via the website.

Name: Thompson Family Funerals
Overview:
At Thompson Family Funeral Directors, we pride ourselves on the individual care and attention to every detail. Located in Castlemaine, Victoria, Australia.

We have grown up in the Mount Alexander area, with the first thompson Settling in Newstead in the 1850's.

The Thompson family has four generations of history in the industry and has been professionally operated for over 60 years. 

We Operate a 24 Hour Service, 7 Days a week


In today’s age, it is surprising to find so little is known of the details concerning the problems bereavement brings. Funeral customs vary greatly all over the world, but largely they have become what they are, because people have decided for themselves the manner in which they wish to honour their departed ones. There seems to be a reluctance to enquire beforehand about the facts surrounding death, although it is one of the most natural happenings in life. Because of that reluctance, additional grief and mental anguish are often added to the normal sorrow which accompanies bereavement, whether it be sudden or expected.

Name: Rainbow Families
Overview: The mission of Rainbow Families is to build a community which fosters resiliency by connecting, supporting and empowering lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer and intersex (LGBTQI ) familiesWho we are Rainbow Families is the peak NSW organisation supporting LGBTQI parents and children. We work with partners and volunteers to deliver a range of programs. These include educational seminars, parenting education, playgroups, and social, community and cultural events. Rainbow Families has introduced a strong voice for LGBTQI parents and their children in NSW, providing advocacy, support and opportunities to celebrate our families.Rainbow Families is governed by a community management committee. We are a not for profit organisation that first convened in early 2015, and has been incorporated since April 2016.  We rely on fundraising, public community grants and private donations to ensure our quality programs continue. Through our program, Rainbow Families works to help those in need to receive the right assistance. In particular, our programs help ensure; •	Families get the right help to support their babies, children and teenagers, including social support and         parenting programs•	Culture, sexual and gender diversity  is acknowledged and celebrated throughout all our service delivery •	Build parents and children’s resilience and reduce systemic and social discrimination experienced by Rainbow         Families •	Celebrate and nurture a supportive community •	LGBTQI parents with experience of depression and post natal depression and anxiety have access to sensitive         information and referral to specialist support •	Support children and young people to build a social support networks •	Empower parents to provide the best care for their children by providing quality parenting programs and         education Contact: info@rainbowfamilies.com.au

Name: Birdwings Forest School
Overview: Birdwings Forest School offers children and families the opportunity to experience a natural childhood. All our programs are 100% outdoors and screen-free, seeking fun and adventure with friends in nature, just as childhood should be. Our small, multi-age groups with adult mentors are reminiscent of the childhood of the 80s: child-led, free, wild and creative. Children are mentored by early childhood professionals experienced in playwork and forest school leadership, supporting children to gain skills for independence, resilience, communication and creative thinking.Birdwings is the Gold Coast's first Forest School offering outdoor programs in rainforests, creeks, farms and bushland. Name: Moira Kelly Creating Hope Foundation
Overview:
The Moira Kelly Creating Hope Foundation builds on Moira’s decades of work caring for sick and needy children and their families. It provides comfort, hope, protection and safety to children and families who need it most.  

Moira is renowned for her work bringing to Australia children with serious health problems that local doctors are unable to treat.  Her Foundation continues this work by providing support for children and families from overseas and from our own community here in Australia who have not been able to receive help elsewhere.  She takes on causes that everybody says no to and she says of her work, “There’s no saying no to hope.”

Ultimately, Moira works to help children and families help themselves, so they can be as fully independent as possible and live full lives in the community.

Moira’s work is funded almost entirely by charitable donations. Her Foundation manages a home in inner suburban Melbourne where the most needy children and families are housed and provided with medical care and support.

Name: Centre for Multicultural Youth
Overview:
The Centre for Multicultural Youth is a Victorian not-for-profit organisation supporting young people from migrant and refugee backgrounds to build better lives in Australia.

Through a combination of specialist support services, training and consultancy, knowledge sharing and advocacy, we are working to remove the barriers young people face as they make Australia their home. 

Our activities include:
* Providing direct one-to-one support for young people with family, housing, education and employment issues.
* Delivering leadership programs that offer young people opportunities to contribute to Australian society.
* Providing training, professional development and consultancy services for organisations to work more effectively with young people.
* Building research evidence and sharing our knowledge.
* Providing evidence-based policy advice and advocacy to decision makers at local, state and national levels.

Name: ACSO Australia
Overview: Our vision is for a community where everyone has the opportunity to thrive, and prison truly is the last resort.Our purpose is to strengthen the wellbeing of communities by advocating for and delivering services which divert people away from the justice system.Our ethos is "Create another chance"​ACSO was founded in 1983 by a man named Stan McCormack, who served a number of years in Pentridge Prison for armed robbery. While Stan was in prison, he underwent a spiritual conversion. There were always people in his cell wanting to talk, or needing advice. When he was released, he created the Epistle Centre; later The Victorian Offender Support Agency for ex-prisoners who were highly disadvantaged. Our founders established support programs and a halfway house (McCormack House) which still remains in operation today. ACSO has expanded over 35 years to deliver services across the eastern seaboard for the intellectually disabled, peopling with mental illness, alcohol and other drug problems, offenders and people with long term unemployment. With a staff of over 440 and an annual turnover of approximately $50m in 2019, ACSO is now a leading Australian NFP, delivering more than 20 life changing programs to approximately 20,000 people a year"It was the sheer determination and drive of founder Stan and his supporters that got ACSO through, even when the foundations seemed to disappear. He was willing, and things happening so fast. There was a lot of help from a lot of people, but the brains and inspiration came from Stan. The best thing was that he took all those blokes in on face value without worrying about their pasts"​

Name: Kids Therapy Club
Overview: The Kids Therapy Club offers various therapy services for children, teens and young adults struggling with disabilities, special needs and disorders. Our goal is to maximize your child’s independent participation in all aspects of their lives. Discovering where to start your child’s therapy is crucial, our team are equipped to properly assess your child and effectively create roadmaps to maximise your child’s potential.Our greatest point of difference is that we have highly experienced therapists who get results, as well as the fact that the club embraces the entire family unit.We are called a club because no child embraces and engages with therapy in a clinical and sterile environment. Our spaces are specifically designed to be a sensory wonderland, where children are inspired to commit and enjoy the therapy process, therefore maximising their potential and making the learning process a far more enjoyable experience. Children and families also have a sense of belonging, as what we provide goes beyond the basic therapy process. Just as each child is different, so are their therapy needs and together with our multidisciplinary team you and your child/children will embark on a tailored program to enable your child to reach their goals effectively.Some of the specific disabilities and disorders we cater to are:Speech and Language Skills  DyspraxiaLearning DifficultiesDevelopmental DelaysIntellectual ImpairmentAutism Spectrum DisorderAspergers SyndromeAttention Deficit DisorderAttention Deficit Hyperactivity DisorderOppositional Defiance DisorderAnxietySensory Processing DisorderYou may have children who do not fall into a category and are simply having difficulty ‘finding their place or understanding’ the expectations or demands of home and school.   We can help them as well.

Name: Jewish House
Overview: About 0.5% of Australians are homeless. This causes many difficulties for the individuals as well as the community at large. At Jewish House, we provide 24/7 Crisis Support to children, women & men of all denominations in need. Our purpose is to assist people in their time of crisis with immediate intervention, crisis accommodation, Rapid Rehousing and various counseling and referral services. Beyond the short term period of crisis intervention our strategy is to use pragmatic and innovative programs to prevent further crises and to facilitate the transition and integration of our clients into the community to lead satisfying lives.Jewish House has also recently launched JH Kids, we work with children aged 4 to 12 preparing for or attending primary school and who are experiencing challenges in learning, well-being, social-emotional or behavioral development. JH Kids believes that it takes a village to raise a child, and so we work with everyone in the child’s ‘village.’ Our professional team uses a holistic approach that identifies the child’s strengths and builds capabilities in parents, siblings and other supporters (schools, grandparents, teachers). This technique of exploring the child’s strengths and building adult capabilities extends the benefits of the skills the child learns. A core theme of our program is to build skills intensely in the beginning, to help a child manage adversity later.

A globally recognised pioneering organisation in ABA research and therapy, the Lovaas Institute is our senior consulting body.We are a not-for-profit organisation. All of our revenue surplus over costs goes to reinforcing and expanding our services, and to subsidising Fair Access for children with autism from financially disadvantaged families."Fair Access is the subsidisation of fees (partial or whole) so that a child with ASD and their family can access L4Life ABA‑based therapy services where, without this subsidy, they could not. Fair Access therefore gives all children with ASD the right to an inclusive and quality educationpromoting life‑long learning."​To learn more about how we can help, please phone our office at (03) 9853 4607, or email us at admin@learningforlife.com.au. Name: Acorn Life Path
Overview:
Acorn Life Path offers a comprehensive financial and personal coaching program for FIFO workers and their families as well as Financial Education packages for employers to offer their employees.

The program is designed to help clients to manage the money and stresses that often accompany working FIFO. 

This includes debt reduction, budgeting, personal financial management, communication and relationship coaching, setting personal and financial goals, and planning life during and after FIFO.

Working with families over a 12 month duration, we create an environment to mentor and educate FIFO (Fly in Fly Out) workers and their families on how to Live for Today While Planning for Tomorrow, how to set and achieve Life Goals, find a Balanced Life and attain Financial Security.

Financial stress is increasingly recognised as having an impact on workplace performance, health and safety, absenteeism and staff retention.  These have a direct impact on the bottom line, and more employers are recognising the benefits of providing their employees with a level of financial education and support.  

Acorn Life Path provide Financial Education Workshops and Financial Coaching and Mentoring through companies who are committed to the holistic welfare of their staff.

Overview:
There are millions of families in Australia, however very few achieve long term wealth and longevity. Even fewer have enshrined family values or traditions which feature as a hallmark of their name. Name: VCC Emergencies Ministry Ltd
Location: 3 Westside Avenue, Unit 30, Port Melbourne, Victoria 3207, AU
Overview: The Victorian Council of Churches Emergencies Ministry began in 1977 and has grown to over 1,600 volunteers who are trained to respond to disasters in Victoria.“The VCC was first brought into disaster recovery work under DISPLAN in 1978 following an approach by the Rev. John Hill regarding the provision of counselling and support services to disaster affected people. As a result, the Victorian Council of Churches through John Hill was asked to chair the counselling sub committee of the Displan Welfare Plan. This committee later evolved to become The Personal Services and Counselling Sub Committee, after the 1983 bushfires, the Community Recovery Committee.” (Smale, S; VCC 1995)The Department of Human Services has contracted the VCCEM to provide outreach, psychological first aid, personal support and emotional spiritual care. The Community Chaplaincy arrangement was initiated in preparation for the 2006 Commonwealth Games with a view to continuing as an element within the State Emergency Recovery Plan (SERP).VCCEM is identified in the Emergency Management Manual of Victoria (EMMV):Prevention / Mitigation / Risk Reduction ActivitiesProvide information, education and training to cultural and faith communities, municipal council emergency management staff and other agencies.Response ActivitiesProvide psychosocial support including emotional spiritual care under the State Health Emergency Response Plan.Relief / Recovery ActivitiesVCCEM supports DHHS to deliver the following relief and recovery activities:1. Provide psychosocial support including psychological first aid, emotional &  spiritual care & personal support in relief & recovery centres and through community outreach, direct visits, community meetings & gatherings. 2. Coordinate the multi-faith,multicultural response to emergenciesassist the Dept of Premier and Cabinet in the development and coordination of state services of worship and assist in the organisation of public memorials & gatherings.

Name: Live Well Longer - Ageing at Home

Overview: Live Well Longer provides independent information to help individuals, and their families, navigate Australia's aged care system to remain living at home. Robyn Massey, Jenni Perkins, and Jill Jamieson, the co-founders of Live Well Longer, are three friends who have come together to share their knowledge and expertise in helping their ageing parents to access services and support to remain living at home. Name: coaching4mums
Overview:
Coaching4mums has been created to help women navigate the complexities of being a mum and a career woman.

Our philosophy is to work directly with mums. Unlike other forms of executive coaching, our contract is only with the mum and never with the organisation so you know we are soley focused on your needs.

If you are returning to work soon we can help you prepare for the conversation with your boss. 

If you are looking to get back into work after an extended break we can help you find your way.

If you are worried about keeping in touch with your career whilst on maternity leave we can help you learn ways to stay relevant. 

If you are in one career but feel it no longer fits we can help you find the new direction you want.

All our services are designed to be flexible around you. We coach over the phone, Skype, face to face and even are happy to combine walking and talking.

Name: Yasminah's Gift of Hope
Overview:
Yasminah's Gift Of Hope provide A Gift Of Hope, support and guidance for premature birth, pregnancy, neonatal and infant loss. Ensuring parents receive early, ongoing support, information and an opportunity to create lasting memories and keepsakes of their time with their child to treasure forever.

Yasminah's Gift Of Hope Journals are a very special keepsake that allows families to keep ultrasound images, photos, cot cards, arm bands, and foot and hand prints as a cherished keepsake of a precious life. We encourage families to write about their journey. The family may like to keep it is a diary during their pregnancy after being told their child has a congenital abnormality, a journey through the roller coaster ride of a Neonatal Intensive Care Unit when their child is born premature, or life after the loss of their child. Some other uses are to write about the birth of their child, write poems about how they are feeling, write a letter to their child and keep any cards or messages received from family or friends.

Most importantly families can write down details and memories about their child to treasure forever. A Gift Of Hope.

Yasminah's Gift Of Hope Incorporated provided our first Gift Of Hope on the 26th May 2010, exactly 1 year and 2 months after Yasminah was born sleeping. Yasminah's Gift Of Hope became a registered non-profit charity endorsed by the Australian Tax Office as a deductible gift recipient on the 13th July 2010. 

We are a volunteer led organisation, many of our volunteers have personally experienced the loss of a child, diagnosis of a congenital abnormality or the premature birth of their child. Our volunteers are dedicated and passionate about providing support and understanding to families during a very difficult time.

Name: Guardian Youth Care
Overview:
Guardian Youth Care (GYC) is an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander controlled, not for profit, residential out of home care provider. The program provides varying residential support options for both Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander and non-Aboriginal children and young people between 12 and 18 years of age. GYC has been operating residential care homes in Sydney for over a decade and has cared for over 300 children and young people in that time. 

GYC seeks to provide a homelike environment for children and young people that promote positive personal change. We firmly believe that positive change is predominately brought about by the positive input provided by Youth Workers. Considering that Youth Workers spend the most time with children and young people in our care, it is logical to expect that the input offered by their function is the most likely to act as a catalyst for positive change. Youth Workers remain positive by adhering to the program principles established at GYC. This principle is particularly relevant when working with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children and young people. At GYC we believe that every child deserves the right to be raised in an environment that connects them with the culture and spiritual heritage.

Guardian Youth Care is an organisation with strong ties to its community, making use of its local knowledge and expertise in its service delivery.

Guardian Youth Care work with and care for children and young people that have been affected by trauma, abuse and neglect. The children and young people have more often experienced multiple placements and require a service that will provide a clear set of practices that really make a difference. 

This Practice Framework seeks to set out Guardian Youth Care’s principles of working with its clients, identify the evidence bases that support the practice the organisation undertakes, and list the techniques that are utilised in supporting the organisation’s clients.

Name: The Nanny Collective
Location: 11 Lang St, 2, Mosman, New South Wales 2088, AU
Overview:
At The Nanny Collective we specialise in placing highly qualified and professional Nannies, Governesses and Babysitters into diverse families with a variety of requirements and demands, whether that be in high profile, executive or regular family households. We offer a professional and personal service to both our clients and candidates and aim to make the hiring process as easy and stress free as possible. 

We understand that choosing quality care for your children is one of the most important decisions you make as a parent so we want to make the process as transparent and smooth as possible.  We are committed to supporting you in providing your little ones the best possible start in life.
______________________________________________________________________________

We will never compromise on the following non-negotiable minimum standards. All of our nanny, governess and babysitter candidates have:

- a minimum of 18 years of age
- a minimum of 2 years experience working with children
- a current Working with Children Check
- a current First Aid Qualification
- a full driver’s license and
- impeccable references

We evaluate candidates based on the following criteria:

- Educational background
- Passion for working with children
- Experience
- Professionalism and drive
- Emotional Intelligence

Candidates are also encouraged to:

- obtain an annual Federal Police Check
- obtain public liability insurance
- hold a minimum childcare qualification as advised by the Australian Children’s Education and Care     Quality Authority (www.acecqa.gov.au)
- Partake in professional development workshops/ seminars


All our governesses, nannies, maternity nurses, mannies and babysitters must pass a vigorous 5 step screening and application process before being put forward for positions.

If you have any questions regarding our services please feel free to contact us at info@thenannycollective.com.au.

Name: Foundations Care
Overview: Foundations Care is a not-for-profit that has been dedicated to serving children and young people, families and communities across Australia for more than 2 decades. Our key services include foster and kinship care, residential care, youth justice services and the caseworker support scheme (NSW). We operate across South-East, South-West and Far North Queensland; across regional New South Wales, including the Hunter-New England region; and across metro and remote Western Australia. In each state our functions are slightly different depending on the state system, but our purpose remains the same – to ensure that the core needs of children and young people to feel safe, accepted and valued within their family and community will be realised. Foundations Care operates from multiple offices across NSW, QLD and WA; our national head office is located in Helensvale, on the Gold Coast, QLD. To achieve the best possible outcomes for children and young, we need a work culture like no other and a team of changemakers, passionate about the protection of children, who feel proud to call Foundations Care home. If you are interested in being a part of our team, a volunteer or you’re interested in becoming one of our carers, please contact us today via our website.

Name: All About Kids
Overview:
Child Youth and Family Allied Health Service

All About Kids Therapy Centre has Psychologists, Counsellors, Social Workers, Speech Language Pathologists, Occupational Therapists, and Dieticians who work with children and youth (birth to 25). 
Children, adolescents and their parents are supported within the clinic by a range of professional assessment, psychological, counselling and therapy services.

Many children and adolescents experience a range of emotional and developmental challenges including anxiety, worry and stress, depression and sadness, anger, grief and loss, trauma, and family separation. Developmental difficulties include speech and language delays, sensory processing problems and motor coordination delays. Difficulties at school may include learning difficulties and disabilities, bullying, and social and friendship issues.

All About Kids provides therapy and assessments for children and adolescents, advice and counselling for families, group programs for children and parents, and professional development for those working with children.

All About Kids has Therapists who specialise in assessment and intervention for Autistic Spectrum Disorders and other developmental disorders, and in assessment and support of children who may be considered gifted and talented.

Name: NSW Family Services Inc / RLG:AU
Overview:
NSW FAMILY SERVICES INC (FamS)

FamS (NSW Family Services Inc) supports non-government organisations in New South Wales that are providing services to families experiencing stress and disadvantage. We encourage and help these organisations to provide quality support services.


RESULTS LEADERSHIP GROUP (RLG)

Results Based Accountability is a disciplined way of thinking and taking action that communities can use to improve the life of children, families and the community as a whole.  RBA can also be used by agencies to improve the performance of their programs and it can be adapted to fit the unique needs and circumstances of different communities and programs. 

The Results Leadership Group designed the Results Scorecard a software tool, based on the principles of RBA, to help government and non-profit organisations maximise the framework’s potential. This includes creating the distinction between population and performance accountability, maintaining language discipline and promoting ends-to-means decision making.  

The Results Scorecard assists users create measurable results for their clients and communities through collaboration, data driven decision making and aligning the performance of programs and initiatives with the impact they create in the community.

Name: West Australian Shalom Group Inc.

Overview: The West Australian Shalom Group is a men’s residential rehabilitation centre located in the heart of the Swan Valley in Perth Western Australia, only 23km from the Perth CBD. Our focus is on bringing restoration to the lives of men and families in our community. At present our program caters for up to 140 men.__________________________________________We offer a holistic rehabilitation program that focuses on bringing restoration to all areas of the resident’s life, including finances, relationships, heart issues, employment, education and training for the future. Our program is practical and hands on, ensuring that residents and all involved in Shalom are valued and contributing members of the community. We offer our services to anyone with a life-controlling issue, whether it be addiction to substances such as drugs and alcohol or people with anxiety, fear or emotional trauma.At Shalom House rehabilitation centre, Perth, our residents always come first in the service we provide. We do whatever we can to give them a safe place to restore their lives and relationships with those they've hurt through their life choices.  The founder of Shalom House rehabilitation centre, Peter Lyndon-James, understands the need for rehabilitation and how hard it is to break free from life controlling issues, having himself come from a background of 26 years in addiction. His struggle to break free from the life that held him captive was a process that taught him a great deal. Peter now uses what he has learned to help set others free from what held him captive for so many years.Shalom House rehabilitation centre in Perth is founded on Christian Principles and at present caters for up to 140 men across ten properties, staffed by qualified and trained personnel. Our staff and volunteers do their utmost in caring for our clients, making them and their progress our priority.

Name: Sydney Homelessness Project
Overview: Finding Home is the vision of one person to solve the homelessness problem in Australia through innovative IT solutions and alternative sources of accommodation.The initial project has a few parts and aims:- to provide a better means of coordination of resources between agencies and organisations who are in the homelessness service area so that resources aren't duplicated or wasted, and to ensure no homeless person slips through the cracks.- to provide a better means of identifying homeless persons, locations, needs and priorities, where homeless details are entered, assessed for priority and a vulnerability assessment made to determine the highest need.- homeless needs notified to service providers in the area.These will be achieved by an App/website and database and geo-referencing where a service operates and the persons location.- to have organisations in Sydney using the App, database and website.- to find temporary and permanent accommodation for people and families in Sydney, and the services they needThe longer term aim is to roll the App, database and website out across Sydney then the rest of AustraliaDetails about homeless persons can be input by service providers, members of the public, a homeless person on themselves or others, police, hospitals, medical staff, council staff and rangers, ambulance. A full assessment can be made later if needed by service providers if full details aren't available.Other functions will be developed and included as well as details of services available to homeless through a dedicated App which is geo-referenced based on the person's location and the area covered or the nearest service provider.This may trigger a Uber type service where an organisation has a food van or street patrol nearby to provide immediate assistance based on the person's needs and location.A directory of available crisis or other temporary accommodation may also be available to homeless in the future through the App similar to AirBNB

Name: Declutter Life
Overview:
Declutter Life offers professional and practical organising services that help you create and maintain spaces that are clutter-free and liberating.

Sorting through clutter accumulated over decades can be difficult and overwhelming. We understand that at this stage of life you want to be free to enjoy what's really important, without feeling weighed down by what's not.

Name: HELLO MOJO App
Overview: In July 2013, within a matter of hours, HELLO MOJO's founder, Annie Kendall went from living the happy, exciting & glamorous life of a Singapore expat to confronting the reality of divorce, no husband, saying goodbye to friends, moving countries, saying hello to lawyers & moving back in with her parents all the while nursing a newborn and running after a toddler.The first few weeks were debilitating but that was only the start of Annie's nightmare. Annie had left herself wide open to financial ruin, The Hague Convention Treaty (which she wasn't even aware of at the time), and with mounting legal bills she now relied on family and government assistance. What followed was 3-years of emotional, physical and financial stress, and hours of documenting everything - all the while feeling hopelessly vulnerable and afraid for what the future may hold. Annie was broken.The only thing Annie had at the time, was her 'love'​ for the children -- and a determination that no-one should ever be thrown into this negative, fear-driven legal space and required to spend more time documenting the details of their split for legal applications and the unknown, instead of attending to their children's needs, healing, co-parenting or learning to move forwards faster, in an empowered way. There was no solution. In 2016, Annie set out to build one. Soon, HELLO MOJO was born.HELLO MOJO gives people a private, highly secure, mobile-based app to streamline the daunting-but-vital admin and documenting process, to reduce stress levels, and save people's time, money and wellbeing.  But, the end of a relationship is more than just documentation: along with the perspiration, people need inspiration. HELLO MOJO Magazine for Women and for Men are supportive, heart-centred publications, and wrap HELLO MOJO's app in a powerful community igniting transformation, healing, inspiration and personal growth. Where does that leave people? Free to get their 'mojo'​ back. Welcome to our tribe!

Name: Smart Pups Assistance Dogs for Special Needs Kids
Overview: Smart Pups Assistance Dogs for Special Needs Children Inc.Smart Pups was the first organisation in Australia to be certified and recognised by the Guide Hearing and Assistance Dog Act 2009: to train task-specific Assistance Dogs for children under 18 years of age. After five years of lobbying, the Founder of Smart Pups finally had the Act amended so that children could have a trained Assistance Dog with an alternative handler. Our goal is to improve the quality of life of children living with autism or seizure related syndromes by training our Assistance Dogs in ‘task specific’ skills - providing safety, companionship, mobility and independence. Our vision is that every child in Australia living with autism, seizure, mobility and diabetes related syndromes will have access to the security and companionship of a Smart Pup Assistance Dog.Smart Pups Autism Assistance Dogs are specially trained to help children who have any disability falling within the Autism Spectrum. These dogs are trained to disrupt behaviour outside of the child's set behavourial pattern. In addition, Autism Assistance dogs can be trained to track the child should he or she wander away. Regardless of what advanced skills Autism Assistance Dogs might be trained to do, their primary purpose is to provide a best friend, confidant and playmate for a child who almost always has few friends.Smart Pups Seizure Alert Assistance Dogs are trained to respond when ‘their’ child is having a seizure, by alerting a parent or guardian adult. This alert response can signal a seizure up to 10 minutes before the seizure actually occurs. This amazing ability can detect seizures well before any existing medical technology.Since 2011, Smart Pups have placed over 90 highly-trained Assistance Dogs with families’ right across Australia – so we can now boast that Smart Pups is truly a national organisation. Although it costs around $28,000 to train each and every Smart Pup, the organisation does not receive any government funding, relying solely on contributions from the recipient family and the unselfish generosity of corporate and community support.

Overview: My Best Life is a National Project aiming to reduce Domestic Violence in Australia and our mission statement is                                RESCUE.REFUGE.RESTORE.RELEASEThe goals of the project are:1  To establish workshops to teach men how to better communicate      with their spouses and children.2  To establish workshops to teach women how to deal with difficult      partners and to re-train women to believe in themselves and their      value. 3  To establish a trained leaders network to facilitate the above. 4  To create a network of safe houses to provide crisis      accommodation for women and children. 5  To provide a network of safe transport options to collect women      and children and transport them to accommodation, hospitals,      police or court as required.6. Name: Happy Hubbub
Overview:
Calling all work-from-home parents! We are building a community of coworking parents in Preston, in Melbourne’s inner north. 

Happy Hubbub is a shared office space with high-speed wifi internet, printing/scanning facilities, networking opportunities and, crucially, an on-site short day care facility, allowing parents of preschoolers to work or study in the Hubbub with their children on-site but not under their feet, being looked after by qualified childcare professionals. 

With more small businesses today being started by women than men – often part-time at first whilst juggling child-rearing – a Hubbub membership will help relieve the pressures of fluctuating business demands, especially as many long daycare centres are unable to provide additional care on an ad-hoc basis or at short notice. 

The Hubbub is also a valuable tool for employers who embrace flexible working arrangements. Allowing employees coming back from parental leave to work remotely out of the Hubbub will ease the transition back to work, enabling parents to get on with their job in a professional setting yet stay close to their child, drop the commute to work and facilitate continued breastfeeding.

Services:
➢	High-speed wifi internet
➢	Bookable meeting rooms and private offices
➢	Printing/scanning facilities
➢	Networking events
➢	Profile in hubbub business directory
➢	Kitchen with espresso coffee machine 
➢	On-site short day care.

Name: Autism Camp Australia
Overview: Autism Camp Australia’s mission is to improve the health and wellbeing of autistic young people and their families through the provision of accessible and supported respite-break experiences, therapies and life skills development.Our vision is self-reliance, independence, social connection and community inclusion for autistic young people and their families.Autism Camp Australia (ACA) is registered with the Australian Securities & Investment Commission (ASIC) as a company limited by guarantee. ACA is registered as a charitable organisation with DGR status, as a Public Benevolent Institution with the Australian Charities and Not-For Profit and Charities Commission (ACNC).The program contributes to significant change in the lives of young people living with ASD by supporting them to:• build self-confidence and communication skills; • develop social skills, create positive connections and increase social interactions with peers, carers and other families;• actively participate in every-day and self-care tasks by nurturing, supporting and encouraging independence;• engage in new activities and to explore, experience and learn from new experiences; • explore sensory and emotional regulation using proprioceptive and sensory supports, games and other positive behaviour support tools; and• make and sustain friendships with their peers.The program contributes to significant change in the lives of parents, carers and siblings of young people living with ASD by supporting them to:• take a break from the day-to-day pressures of being a carer;• be valued and appreciated for their contribution to their family and community;• connect with other families/carers, share stories, information and family strategies;• make and sustain friendships with other families/carers of autistic young people; and• take part in parenting/carer and sibling support programs through education and information workshops.

Name: Bledisloe Australia Pty Ltd
Overview:
BLEDISLOE GROUP HOLDINGS

Bledisloe Group Holdings Pty Ltd,  (incorporating Bledisloe Australia Pty Ltd and Bledisloe New Zealand Pty Ltd) is an Australian owned private Company specifically formed in 2001 to purchase the Australian and New Zealand funeral operations owned by an American Corporation, 

 In 2005 the Company was partly acquired by private equity interests investing Australian superannuation funds.

Bledisloe Australia is the second largest owner and operator of funeral homes in Australia with funeral operations in Queensland, NSW, Tasmania and Victoria. In New Zealand, Bledisloe is the largest owner and operator.

Many of our funeral homes have been providing funeral services to families for decades, some for centuries. All of our business operations maintain and use their existing trading names to maintain the goodwill within the community that has been built up over many years. 

The name Bledisloe was chosen to reflect the fact that the company has funeral operations in both countries, and to reflect the values of community and civic responsibility that Lord Bledisloe promoted when he was Governor General of New Zealand in the early 1930’s, as we felt those values also reflected the role we play in the community.

Bledisloe Holdings assists approximately 11,000 families with their funeral arrangements annually in Australasia through over 300 dedicated staff in more than 50 mostly owned locations. Many of Bledisloe’s businesses have been serving local communities for over 100 years. In Queensland our main business is Metropolitan Funerals; in NSW, Gregory & Carr Boland Funerals; and in Victoria, W D Rose & Joseph Allison Funerals.

In both countries we abide by a strict internal standard of Policy, Ethics and Codes
of Conduct, and our entire funeral homes exceed the minimum standards of premises equipment and vehicles stipulated by Industry Associations.

Name: PREPARE/ENRICH Australia
Overview:
PREPARE/ENRICH is a customised couple assessment completed online that identifies a couple's strength and growth areas. It is one of the most widely used programs for premarital counselling and premarital education and is also used for marriage counselling, marriage enrichment, and dating couples considering engagement. Based on a couple's assessment results, a trained facilitator provides 3 or more feedback sessions in which the facilitator helps the couple discuss and understand their results as they are taught proven relationship skills.

PREPARE/ENRICH has a nation-wide team of Trainers and Facilitators and continues to provide training and ongoing skills development for people eager to work with the PREPARE/ENRICH program in Australia. Apart from USA and Australia, there are international offices in New Zealand, Canada, United Kingdom, Germany, Japan, Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore, Sweden and South Africa.

PREPARE/ENRICH Australia has provided training coordination and quality administration and development services since 1979, supporting its mission ‘to build strong marriages and healthy relationships’. The PREPARE/ENRICH tool is the peak inventory (assessment) in Australia, with over 200,000 couples having participated in the program in the past thirty years (over 3 million globally).

Name: Coastlink - Central Coast
Location: Level 2, 7/10 William Street, Gosford, New South Wales 2250, AU
Overview: Coastlink provides family-focused and people-centred care to people at all stages of life who have a physical, intellectual, sensory, social or age-related disability. Our purpose is to improve the daily lives of the people we assist to help them maintain independence and make connections within our community.Operating for more than 30 years, Coastlink is the number one disability and aged care provider on the Central Coast. Coastlink offers opportunities for social interaction, engagement and skill development for young people and adults living with disability. We provide individual assistance and support to help people living with disability to lead fulfilled and independent lives. We also support seniors to remain living independently at home, and provide programs to allow them to connect, engage and contribute to our community.We coordinate regular activities between Sydney, the Central Coast and Newcastle, and run community centre programs at Mangrove Mountain, Patonga and Green Point. Managing a customised fleet of buses enables easy access to these services and activities. In 2018, Coastlink opened its first group home, Rainford Lodge.Coastlink is funded by the NSW Department of Family and Community Services, the NSW Department of Ageing, Disability and Home Care, and the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS). Our seniors’ services are currently funded primarily by the Commonwealth Home Supports Program (CHSP).

Name: Northern Rivers Community Gateway
Overview: Northern Rivers Community Gateway began in 1976 to provide welfare services to people in Lismore, where our community hub still exists today, providing support and relief to the most disadvantaged people in the area. Our diverse range of direct support and community building programs now extends to the Far North Coast, New England, Mid North Coast and across New South Wales.Our purpose is four-fold. We deliver programs and services that support socially and economically disadvantaged people in overcoming their barriers to living healthy, happy lives. We provide facilities and resources in our community to increase harmony, connection, engagement and social capacity. We advocate for diversity, social justice and the empowerment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. We create opportunities for welfare service users to be self determining and have a voice in the decisions that affect their lives.We are governed by a board of management made up of individuals from a range of professional fields. We have a passionate and professional workforce of over 65 staff and 500 registered volunteers. Funding for our programs and services comes from a variety of agencies, sponsors, fundraising and social enterprise initiatives.Our vision is "many tracks, one road, sustaining community."​ Our organisational values are vision, commitment, integrity, respect and innovative. These values underpin all the work that we do.

Name: The Last Hurrah Funerals
Overview: Our mission is simple: First, to offer reasonably priced and uniquely personal farewells, funerals, and end of life rituals that reflect each individual’s authentic self. Second, to offer a gentle and secure circle of support to those grieving a loss.The Last Hurrah Funerals caters for all people of all nations, cultures, subcultures, and persuasions. Secular and atheist funerals are a speciality, and earth-based rituals and ceremonies are thoroughly catered for. The Last Hurrah team supports all kinds farewells from no-fuss funerals, body donations or memorial-only farewells to lengthy vigils, the family taking the deceased home to lie in state, or at our venue, late-night wakes for weeping and rousing remembrance, shroud burial, DIY funeral assistance, and more.The Last Hurrah hold no specific ethos in regard to how the dead should be farewelled; instead our primary aim is to support those who are grieving to farewell their kith and kin in a way that is meaningful to them, and to create funerals and rites that truly and authentically reflect the person who has died.

Name: Susanne Nelson and Associates
Overview:
Susanne Nelson and Associates provides comprehensive and holistic therapy services to children and families with autism spectrum disorders. Susanne Nelson formed the practice as an Outreach provision in 2006, as she believes that therapy should be delivered in the environment where the child’s needs are the greatest.

SNAA provides an “Outreach Therapy Service” to your child either in your family home or your child’s Kindergarten or School setting.  Susanne Nelson formed this therapy service as an Outreach provision in 2006, as she believes that therapy should be delivered in the setting where the child’s needs are the greatest.

In her clinical experience, Susanne has found that therapy is most effective when “A teaching teacher model” is applied to the child’s parents, carers or educators in the appropriate setting.  This model ensures that your child not only learns the skills in the environment that is required, but also provides the carers/educators with the professional knowledge and strategies that can be carried over after each therapy session has been conducted.

At SNAA, the Therapists work very closely with you, your child and all team members within your child’s care.  In order to achieve this, we set up a “Student/ Parent Support Group email” system, whereby all team members (with your consent), can get access to our therapy progress notes after each therapy session has been conducted.  This is a way for all members to continually share knowledge and information about your child’s therapy program and coupled with the “teaching the teacher model”, contributes to your child’s ability to generalize the skills across all settings.

SNAA utilises a “Family Centred Practice” framework, and incorporates their interests of cognitive behavioural/affective training, anxiety management, social skills and sensory modulation when working with your child and family.

Name: Australian African Foundation for Retention and Opportunity (AAFRO)
Overview: The Australian African Foundation for Retention and Opportunity (AAFRO) is an organisation created and driven by African communities in Melbourne to build a bridge between young people from a range of cultures and the wider Australian community. The organisation hosts forums and activities to promote positive mutual engagement with schools, and the local community with the aim of securing partnerships and sponsorship of educational programs, skills workshops and community outreach in order to advance the self-development of young Australians and their families.AAFRO takes a holistic approach to developing young Australians, through an emphasis on educational assistance, work and life skills, the family environment and wider community. AAFRO has the following objectives:•	To directly assist, encourage and facilitate the integration into Australian society of new arrivals through education, cultural and practical advice and to re-establish economic and emotional independence so as to assist in overcoming the effects of, poverty, domestic violence, distrust of law enforcement authorities and distress caused by war and related events. •	To assist and support young new arrivals by assisting in fluency in the English language and life skills. •	To develop and provide policies and programs in relation to the prevention of homelessness, isolation and unlawful activity, and to provide educational opportunities to improve economic and social circumstances for youth at risk and who are known to the justice system.•	To allow AAFRO to assist families and youth within other countries.

Name: Nordoff-Robbins Music Therapy Australia
Location: Building E, UWS, Second Avenue, KINGSWOOD, NSW 2747, NSW 2747, AU
Overview:
WHO WE ARE
Nordoff Robbins Music Therapy Australia is an inspirational, not-for-profit organisation providing Clinical Music Therapy and Community Music Programs. We deliver outstanding health outcomes for our clients and transform their lives through music.

WHAT WE DO
Our network of highly trained and accredited music therapists works with people of all ages and with a wide range of abilities and conditions. We deliver thousands of music therapy sessions per year in (aged) care homes, community settings, hospitals, (special needs) schools, disability organisations and our own centres around New South Wales. We also offer supported music lessons and a rich diversity of workshops and professional supervision/education forums.

Through music we can help to:
•	Improve physical health and ability
•	Address emotional and behavioural difficulties
•	Develop communication and social skills
•	Increase creativity, self-esteem and confidence

WHO WE HELP
Our clinics service a broad range of clients and we specialise in providing music-based programs that deliver positive outcomes for :
•       Physical and intellectual disabilities 
•	Early Intervention needs
•	Mental health diagnoses
•	Speech and language disorders
•	Autism Spectrum Disorder
•	Emotional and behavioural difficulties 
•	Dementia and ageing 
•	Family relationship difficulties
•	Stroke and brain injury rehabilitation 

Our work often complements other interventions including speech therapy, occupational therapy, physiotherapy, counselling and behaviour management plans. Our therapists often work together with other services to strengthen client’s outcomes.

Name: leukodystrophyresourceresearch
Overview: The Leukodystrophy Resource & Research Organisation Incorporated (LRRO) and the Australasian Leukodystrophy Foundation (ALF) were started by Bob Wyborn to meet an urgent Australasian need to supply and support Resources and Research into all the Leukodystrophies and those Leukoencephalopathies that may be closely allied. Bob became involved after his 11-year-old son Brendan died from Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) in 1999.Both Australian organisations are based in Queensland with an extensive network throughout Australia and the world. The ALF is the overseas arm whilst the LRRO operates in Australia. These organisations are very informative, educative and actively pursuing the latest progression in scientific, medical and social research, which will enhance the lives of those, affected by Leukodystrophy and their families and friends. The web sites have the same content.The goal is to maximise the care to the Leukodystrophy families of Australasia and to enable them to access all available resources and to be part of the worlds research programs. The holistic approach taken will advance the ultimate aim of determining a cure for the individual Leukodystrophies.

Name: Chapter House Funerals
Overview: At Chapter House, we support you from the very first conversation. Whether we begin with a phone call from a hospital, a family member or a friend, our Funeral Directors are available at any time of day to take your loved one into our care.Together, we then craft a meaningful story that respects, honours and celebrates each individual. Because this is their unique story, told at your pace. And always with our warmth and understanding. Our Funeral Directors are happy to meet you at our offices at 101 Collins Street in the Melbourne CBD, at High Street Kew, or at your home. Wherever you feel most comfortable.Traditional funerals:We offer traditional funeral services with a truly personal touch. These ceremonies can be held at a religious venue or in our beautifully appointed and welcoming space in Kew. This can then be followed by a second service at a crematorium or cemetery. As always, we will be guided by you, so that we provide the appropriate support for you and your family. Memorials:Just as each life is different, each story can be told in a different way. A memorial is typically a gathering that defies convention. It could be held in a local park, a favourite bar, a private gallery, a beautiful winery, or a family home. It can take place anywhere, at any time, and promises to be as unique as the individual being celebrated.Our Funeral Directors work with you to first secure a venue. We then help to arrange anything from music and readings to invitations and wine. The important element to remember is that a memorial service does not follow any rules. It’s just whatever feels right to you.The community:Chapter House is a part of your local community – a house that hosts events, art shows, workshops, and more. With strong connections to charities and local groups, we work to cherish lives in as many ways as possible.

Overview: The St Vincent de Paul Society is a volunteer based international charity that offers a ‘hand up’ to people experiencing disadvantage.The St Vincent de Paul Society is a ground-roots organisation whose members and volunteers have been helping countless families and individuals for more than 150 years. Name: Forsight
Location: Suite 508, Level 5, 63-79 Parramatta Road, Silverwater, New South Wales 2128, AU
Overview: WHO WE AREForsight is a for-purpose organisation that provides supported accommodation for people with sensory impairments across Greater Western Sydney and Wollongong.Our values are at the core of our culture and we take pride in fostering an attitude in our homes that places our clients at the centre of everything we do. WHAT WE DO𝗦𝘂𝗽𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝗜𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗽𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗟𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗦𝗵𝗼𝗿𝘁-𝗧𝗲𝗿𝗺 𝗔𝗰𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗺𝗼𝗱𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻Within our homes, we provide a safe, comfortable and nurturing environment. Tailored pathways based on the requirements of our clients put quality at the centre of all that we do to help empower every person to live their best life possible.𝗦𝘂𝗽𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁 𝗖𝗼𝗼𝗿𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻Our experienced team will put your needs first to help you move toward the quality of life you desire and your goals. They will ensure you get the most suitable supports for them without having to wait for long periods of time.𝗕𝗲𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗶𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗦𝘂𝗽𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗧𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗮𝗽𝘆Our Allied Health team provide Therapy and Behaviour Support services that work in collaboration with your support network to ensure everyone has a shared understanding of your needs and how to work toward your goals.OUR HISTORYOur story begins at the North Rocks Central School for Blind and Deafblind Children. In 1978, we were established by a group of parents and teachers who wanted to ensure that their children had a pathway to independent living as young adults and beyond. We were the world’s first public-education and parent-run organisation with the aim of providing supported accommodation for people who are blind or deafblind. Former students from the school were the first co-residents of our very first home, which opened in Ashfield in 1983 as Australia’s first family group home.

Name: Career Shift
Location: 12/40 Blackwood Street Mitchelton, Open Building Complex, Second Floor, Mitchelton, QLD 4053, AU
Overview: Career Shift commenced it’s journey in 2010 as a career transition provider, assisting individuals exiting the ADF with transition CVs, interview skilling, career coaching, job seeking assistance and canvassing.   In 2014 Career Shift underwent it’s own transition, becoming a Comcare accredited rehabilitation provider focused specifically on medically discharged ADF members.  By this time Career Shift had developed a strong team including vocational and allied health professionals.  As a result Career Shift’s steadfast commitment to military transition and rehabilitation of veterans has been recognised by DVA and the ADF, with numerous opportunities to meet with key stakeholders to provide comment and influence change. Career Shift has facilitated over a thousand return to work programs that have succeeded and converted to employment.  Our team understands what the key indicators are that create these successful outcomes.  Whilst the result achieved is meaningful and sustainable employment for the veteran, this is the tip of the iceberg of the actual journey that the ADF member undertakes with Career Shift.  The facilitated journey that Career Shift creates is what we can truly claim success for, our unique expertise show respect to veteran’s very personal transition and the impact to their families.

Name: Victorian Foundation for Survivors of Torture Inc – Foundation House
Overview: Foundation House provides services to advance the health, wellbeing and human rights of people of refugee backgrounds in Victoria who have experienced torture or other traumatic events in their country of origin or while fleeing those countries.The organisation was established in Melbourne in 1987 and is non-denominational, politically neutral and non-aligned. It is constituted as a not-for-profit organisation managed by an elected Board of Management. Our work is funded by the Victorian and Commonwealth Governments, charitable organisations and donations from private individuals.We:• Provide services to clients in the form of individual and family support, advocacy, group work, psycho-education, information and complementary therapies• Work with client communities to improve their capacity to access the services they need and to enable them to support recovery• Offer professional and organisational development, consultancy and resources to assist health, education, employment and other community service providers, to enhance the responsiveness of their services to the needs of people of refugee backgrounds• Work with the Victorian and Commonwealth Governments to ensure that policies and programs have proper regard to the needs of people of refugee backgrounds• Conduct and contribute to research about the needs of people of refugee backgrounds and the best possible ways of meeting those needsWorking throughout Victoria, Foundation House is a state-wide agency offering services in metropolitan, regional and rural areas. We have over 200 staff working across five main locations. Our Head Office is located in Brunswick. Our Metropolitan Offices are located in Dallas (Northern), Dandenong (South Eastern), Ringwood (Eastern) and Sunshine (Western). We also provide services in partnership with other agencies in Ballarat, Bendigo, Geelong, Mildura, Shepparton, Swan Hill and the Latrobe Valley.

Staff are committed to Goodwin's mission, values and vision and are dedicated to the continual improvement of aged care practices across Australia.

Name: Living My Way Limited
Location: Ground Floor, 44-60 Allison Crescent, Menai, Sydney, NSW 2234, AU
Overview: Living My Way Limited is a Not-For-Profit organisations supporting people with a disability since 1992 to be empowered to live life their way. Living My Way Ltd (formerly known as Allowance Inc until 2014) was formed in 1992 by a group of people with severe physical disabilities which was led by disability rights advocate, the late Kevin Byrne AM. However, this organisation really dates back prior to its formation. The founding group was among the first to take part in a pilot study of Australia’s first Attendant Care Allowance Model (a self-managed package) initiated during the 1980s by the Commonwealth government.The government invited 24 individuals with varying disabilities and lifestyles to apply for the opportunity to participate in a study that would enable them to have choice and control by becoming registered employers for two years. The notion of a person with a disability having choice and control in the 1980s was groundbreaking and unheard of in the ‘world of disability’.The creation of the Allowance Model was life changing. Being ‘in the driver’s seat’ not only met their needs, but the hours could be adapted to suit individual lifestyles, and offered flexibility that enabled the pursuit of social, recreational and career objectives.Our services allow Members to employ their own staff along with provide them with the freedom to get back to living. To that end, we also work alongside our Members to ensure they always feel supported on their journey.  We are a Registered NDIS Plan Manager, Occupational Therapy, Clinical Nursing, Personal Care, Community Aceess, Support Coordination Service Provider under the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS).

Name: Caretakers Cottage Inc.
Overview:
About Us

Caretakers Cottage assists kids and young people facing homelessness, providing a range of specialist children, teenage and young peoples services across the East and South East Sydney region. In partnership with Family and Community Services, Community Housing providers and other Government and NGO agencies, we offer a unique program of accommodation, support and after-care services to improve outcomes, reduce homelessness and provide opportunities for stable and independent transition into adulthood.

Broadly, we provide two different models of care with the first being Specialist Homelessness Services (SHS) run through Caretakers Cottage Youth Refuge, providing crisis accommodation and support for 13 - 17 year olds for up to 3 months and Options Youth Housing, which provides semi-independent transitional accommodation for young people from 16 - 25, who are at risk of or currently experiencing homelessness.

The other model of care is Out Of Home Care (OOHC) accommodation specifically for young people who have been placed into the care of the Minister of Community Services. Our OOHC services are intensively staffed and are run through Entity and Horizon.

Name: CoordiKids
Overview: CoordiKids helps children facing sensory processing, fine or gross motor challenges access world class, fun and affordable occupational therapy exercises and activities from the comfort of their preferred place of learning (such as at home, in the classroom or outdoors).CoordiKids founder Marga Grey (MSc OT) is a passionate paediatric occupational therapist who has specialised in children’s sensory, fine and gross motor skill integration for over 20 years.She created and developed an innovative online series of over 200 clinically acclaimed occupational therapy exercises and activities over eight developmental levels for children between the ages of 4 and 17, which can be accessed from the comfort of home or classroom setting.Marga’s primary objectives for CoordiKids are accessibility, affordability and fun.“I knew I needed to translate my three decades of experience in OT into exercises and activities of no more than 20 minutes duration to help children reach their true potential,” said Marga.“I feel so blessed that we have been able to support thousands of children through our home, kindergarten, classroom and consultation session programs and are now active in 5 countries and growing / expanding.”

Name: Mums Angels Domestic Cleaning
Overview:
You can buy your time back by using us.

Mum's Angels is a Brisbane cleaning company servicing Brisbane and the areas of Gold Coast, Moreton Bay and Ipswich that prides itself on old fashioned high standards of service and customer care. We offer you handpicked contractors assessed through a thorough interview process. All Mum's Angels contractors are police checked.

Your cleaner is fluent in the art of detailing and given an adequate amount of time will be able to tend to the little things you may never have time for. Fridges, ovens and windows can easily be part of a routine.

You are able to rely on your cleaner to focus on fulfilling your needs.


Regular Weekly, Fortnightly & monthly Cleaning
 3 hour minimum The cleaners are police checked and covered for public liability insurance. You will have the same cleaner every time for as long as you are comfortable with each other. 

Your cleaner will do as much as is reasonably expected within the time that you choose to allocate to the task. Your cleaner can easily fit into a set routine with an extra job or two to fill any left over time. Alternately the cleaner can perform different tasks on each visit. Our job description is to fulfil your domestic cleaning and housekeeping needs.

 Clearspace is an aspect of Mums Angels Cleaning that is unique and specialised.

I work with hoarders that are ready to turn their home and lives around. Those first steps can be overwhelming and stop you in your tracks.

We work together in your home one room at a time, sorting through acres of items, setting achievable goals, and putting systems in place.

All the ‘stuff’ that you are ready to let go of I bag and take away on the day. One of my passions in life is to recycle as much as possible, giving to organisations for animals & individuals in need.

Clearing can be very emotional. I am trained and continue to learn ways in which to support you emotionally and compassionately through this time.

Name: Family Relationships Institute Inc. trading as RelateWell
Location: Suite 102, 398 Sydney Road, Coburg, VIC 3058, AU
Overview:
The Family Relationships Institute Inc. is a not-for-profit educational community agency governed by a Board of Management. The Institute has no affiliations with any religious or political organisation; and is funded by the Australian Government Department of Social Services (DSS).

The Family Relationships Institute Inc. was founded in 1978 by Don Burnard, a Senior Psychologist who specialised in relationship development courses; and Dr Ron Fitzgerald who was a Commissioner for the Education Section of the Henderson Poverty Report.

The objectives of the Institute are to provide, at signficant life stages, family and relationship education and counselling services to assist individuals, couples, families and children engage in community life and navigate life events. Our RelateWell courses help participants recognise that they have the potential to be the experts in shaping their future lives; and in maintaining fulfilling and meaningful relationships and family life. Our education and counselling services are primarily in early intervention and prevention and target the significant family transition points including relationship formation, extension and separation.

The Institute aims to provide programs and services at a price which keeps them within financial reach of the majority of people in the community. Strengthening access and services to vulnerable and disadvantaged families is a strategic key in service delivery.

The Institute is incorporated under the Associations Incorporation Act.

Name: Zipporah Oliver O.A.M. Psychologist
Location: 13 Kurrajong Ave, St. Kilda East, Victoria 3183, AU
Overview: Zipporah Oliver O.A.M. is a registered psychologist based in St Kilda East, Melbourne.With over 24 years of experience providing a professional, skilled and ethical psychological service, Zipporah is committed to enhancing the psychological and emotional wellbeing of her clients.Having high ambitions for your career or personal life is frequently paired with increased stress levels, which may result in feelings of overwhelm and anxiety, and can affect other areas life – especially with the relationships of loved ones. Some symptoms that are commonly experienced by this stress include depression, anxiety, insomnia, panic attacks, and low self-esteem to name but a few. The counselling process can help you deal with difficult problems, however, it does not always have to be problem-based. You may elect to utilise counselling to address deeper issues in order to optimise your life and gain clarity on the pathways you need to undertake to achieve your goals. The coaching element of counselling can enhance functioning, especially juggling the work/life challenge.Knowing time is money and working with clients based all over the world, Zipporah offers phone and Skype sessions for all my clients, as well as “in person” appointments in my practice based in East St Kilda. Zipporah offers a 10-minute discovery call to gauge whether and how she can help you if you would like to know whether she is the right fir for you. Please feel free to contact her on 0438 345 770 or send an email to people@zoliver.com.au to organise a time. Zipporah counsels adults, couples and adolescents for:AnxietyChallenging adolescent behaviourCoping with health changesCouples therapyDepressionDispute resolutionDisability-related issuesFamily and relationship issuesLife/Personal coachingPanic disorderParental supportPeace MakingPhobiasPsychosomatic illnessRelationships counsellingSelf-esteem and self-developmentStress, life changes and navigating crisisWomen’s issues

Name: South Port Community Housing Group
Overview:
South Port Community Housing Group is a government-funded community-managed organisation whose primary focus is to assist people on low incomes in South and Port Melbourne who are experiencing housing difficulty.

We respond to two main issues:
	
1.The loss of affordable single-room accomodation available to people on low incomes with our Rooming House Program. 	

People on pensions and benefits, young people, and people who are ill or disabled have great difficulty in obtaining good, secure accomodation in today's market, particularly in the inner suburbs.

For many people especially those with limited mobility, it is important that they can live close to friends, relatives, doctors and community services.

2.Youth homelessness with our Youth Housing Program Accommodation for those aged between 15-24 who are homeless or insecurely housed.

Name: Family Based Care Tasmania
Overview: Family Based Care Tasmania (FBC) has been a leading force in the provision of community services in Tasmania for 30 years.  At FBC we aim to make a difference to those who may be struggling with independent living – whether it be due to ill health, age or disability – by providing various forms of assistance. FBC support services help our clients to live independently in their homes for as long as possible.FBC is an approved provider of Home Care Packages and support services under the National Disability Insurance Scheme.  Our service areas include domestic assistance, personal care, meal preparation, social support, assistance with shopping, respite and home maintenance and wellness and reablement.  FBC also offers an affordable support service to individuals who are not eligible for government assistance.In February 2018, FBC expanded its business interests through the acquisition of Tidswell Consulting and Vocational Assessment Centre.  Through this acquisition FBC’s service delivery model now includes professional Vocational Rehabilitation and Vocational Services. This is great news for Tasmanians who may be disadvantaged in the labour market - whether by injury, disability, education and vocational preparation deficits, or unemployment.  Based out of our offices in Burnie, Devonport and Launceston, our highly skilled and qualified staff provide support services to over 1120 clients across northern Tasmania.  FBC is proud to be an Employer of Choice.An ISO 9001 accredited association, Family Based Care was so named for our family friendly philosophy; a philosophy which has been sustained through the growth of the business, from its humble beginnings through to the vibrant and progressive organisation that it is today.

FamS is the peak body for the child and family sector. We support non-government, not-for-profit organisations working with vulnerable children and families.


FamS has always been driven by strong values, and our vision is:

- Safe Children
- Strong Families
- Supportive Communities


We provide support to our members to contribute to population outcomes through:

- Systematic policy and advocacy: to inform and enable the government to implement solutions that support vulnerable children and families.

- Building skills and knowledge in outcomes-based frameworks to enable organisations to collect and use data to inform practice and collaborate to provide better results for clients, practitioners and organisations.

Name: Sexual Lives & Respectful Relationships
Overview: Sexual Lives & Respectful Relationships or SL&RR (formerly Living Safer Sexual Lives: Respectful Relationships or LSSL:RR) uses a community-driven and collaboratively developed model to deliver a peer-led relationships and sexuality program for people with disabilities in local communities. It was developed in collaboration with people with intellectual disability and University researchers.People with intellectual disability are trained as Peer Educators to run the program in collaboration with community sexual health and sexual assault response professionals who are trained as Program Partners.Together peer educators and Program Partners form local networks that work together to promote, further develop and evaluate the program and to connect it to other abuse prevention work locally.This model and program are unique. It focuses on ideas of rights, privacy and safety within relationships using stories told by people with disability and gathered through life story research. People with disabilities are engaged throughout the program and drive the ongoing development of the model.SL&RR is currently ran in : - Gippsland- Central Victoria (Bendigo)- Western Melbourne - Barwon (Geelong)- Northern Melbourne- Mornington Peninsula- South-western Sydney- Southern Sydney- Blue Mountains

Name: Australian Multiple Birth Association (AMBA)
Overview:
Formed in 1974, the Australian Multiple Birth Association is the only national support organisation for multiple-birth families and individuals in Australia.

AMBA is a not-for-profit organisation consisting of multiple birth families to whom we provide support, resources and education from other families sharing the same unique journey. With no paid staff, AMBA’s board and clubs are managed and operated by volunteer parents of multiples from all walks of life and experience.

AMBA is active in supporting families, increasing awareness of the unique needs of multiple birth families, improving the resources made available to them and producing and distributing literature on issues relating to multiples.

Today there are multiple birth clubs in every state and territory of Australia, with membership of around 4,000 families.

Name: The Care List Home
Location: Unit 310, 166 Glebe Point Road, Glebe, NSW 2037, AU
Overview: The Care List is an Australian Government approved home care package provider.We have created a revolutionary model to deliver Home Care Packages under the Aged Care Act 1997 to enable elder Australians to stay at home longer as an alternative to entering a Residential Aged Care facility.Our model addresses 4 key objectives that address the problems that plague the Home Care Package programme.For Home Care Package recipients and those who do not yet have a Home Care Package, these objectives are:Control - You have total control over who provides the services you need. It can be your preferred local service provider or someone recommended by a friend. You can control who is sent to you, not your package provider.Choice - It's your choice. You choose the services you want. You choose when services are provided. You choose service providers that you know and like, or use trusted providers sourced and recommended by us.Cost - We charge a very small percentage of your package funds in fees. We charge much less than the industry average, and our charges are always crystal clear and up front - no hidden surprises. This leaves you with more money to spend on the services you want.Convenience - If you don't want the hassle of dealing with service providers, let us do the the work for you. Busy families need peace of mind too. We offer a 'Care List Carer'​ service which can take care of booking services, monitoring services provided, accounting for package funds, and dealing with emergencies etc.To learn more, please visit www.thecarelist.com.au
