Name: RESPITE NOW (Melbourne)
Location: Level 1, 609 Camberwell Rd., Camberwell, VIC 3124, AU
Overview:
Respite Now is a new breed of best practice, in-home aged and disability carers providing specialist attention to seniors and  disabled people. Working with what our clients CAN do rather than what they CAN’T means they enjoy a richer array of activities and functionality; with safety, independence, dignity and pleasure formulating the critical features of our care-plans. 

Utilisng proven developmental strategies, guidance from our unique RITCHLY values and stringent recruitment and HR policies may create the difference your loved one needs to ensure their happiness and health remains as high as possible for as long as possible. We include help around the house, transportation to medical appointments, meal preparation, reading sessions or just someone to spend quality time with.  Respite Now will demonstrate how our ClientCarerMatchmaker can often transform client’s attitudes and well being.  By ensuring the relationship with the carer is matched from day one and the care-plan is sensitive and focused on the sensory, motor, social and cognitive strengths of each client, we are confident that the care they receive will be as good as it can get.

We specialise in multi-lingual carers so if a particular language or cultural background is required, no 
problem; let us work our magic with our trademarked ClientCarerMatchmaker system. We will never allow a stranger into your house. Each carer is first shortlisted and selected with our client's help and are personally introduced by one of our company directors prior to the carer being appointed. Our client's always have the last say.

Our 24/7 availability means even if urgent response is required, we can put things in place to ensure nothing is left to chance.

Name: Codes 4 Life
Location: 475 Stuart Hwy, Alice Springs, Northern Territory 0870, AU
Overview: Codes 4 Life is an Aboriginal men’s program that seeks to address and curb unlawful behaviour stemming from alcohol and substance abuse, including drink driving, domestic violence, and sexual assault. The program drives reformation and personal change by delivering workshops designed to reconnect Aboriginal men with their culture and cultural responsibilities.One of the main issues that Codes 4 Life addresses is, participants are often plagued with questions surrounding their identity. The program channels this uncertainty into a sense of leadership by instilling a sense of responsibility to culture and community. The workshops focus on embracing culture and finding strength in one’s role in their community.Codes 4 Life is led by Program Manager Michael Liddle and supported by Project Officer Wayne Scrutton. All workshops are overseen by Aboriginal Elders or senior community leaders. The program also works closely with the police and community support programs to effectively deliver comprehensive workshops."For a man on the straight path of Aboriginal law, the journey that takes us from being boys to being men, the answers are clear. That journey teaches us our rules, our responsibilities and obligations. We look at all the issues around our business, and the destructive aspects that alcohol is playing, and the trouble and despair that it is playing with our ability to continue the knowledge around country. The question is put to the group that, ‘Somewhere, someway, you are an owner of country; you are a caretaker of country and you can’t be looking after country if you are in jail. When you are in jail, you miss a lot of ceremony, you miss a lot of law, and you also miss a lot of meetings where you are needed to sit with your Elders and assist them to understand.’"-Michael Liddle

Overview:
House and Pet Sitters is a professional Perth-based house sitting and pet minding service operated by a team of mature animal lovers.

All our sitters have undergone an extensive induction process and have valid Police Clearance certificates. 
Our sitters are fully insured and most importantly each sitter is an animal lover who will take care of your pet/s and home according to your specific requests.

We have sitters available for short and long stays.

Shared disability homes specially designed and built by Secure Housing address these issues creating an atmosphere of hope to live a fruitful, sustained, and happy life with friends.Improving the pathway between the NDIS, health, and aged care to prevent young people being discharged from hospitals into nursing homes is paramount to our society. Name: Ballarat & District Aboriginal  Co-operative (BADAC)

Overview: Members of the Ballarat and district Aboriginal community established the Ballarat and District Aboriginal Co-operative (BADAC) in 1979. BADAC delivers a comprehensive range of health, social, welfare and community development programs to local Aboriginal people. Since 1979, the organisation has grown considerably to a staff of 120 delivering a wide range of services, underpinned by Social Inclusion principles, which incorporate the following programs: Health and Home Care Social and Emotional Well-being Family Support Care Services Family Violence and Justice Early Years and YouthBADAC is the Aboriginal Community-Controlled Organisation (ACCO) for the Ballarat and district area, covering 4 local government areas (LGAs). Our services are open to all members of the public, with priority given to our members. BADAC is focused on prevention and early intervention, always with a client-centred approach, to ensure that our clients are personally engaging in the development and nurturing of their own futures.

Name: Parents Under Pressure
Overview: The Parents Under Pressure (PuP) program combines psychological principles relating to parenting, child behavior and parental emotion regulation within a case management model. The program is home-based and designed for families in which there are many difficult life circumstances that impact on family functioning. Such problems may include depression and anxiety, substance misuse, family conflict and severe financial stress. The program is highly individualized to suit each family. Parents are given their own Parent Workbook. For many parents, this becomes a personal journal of their treatment experience. The overarching aim of the PuP program is to help parents facing adversity develop positive and secure relationships with their children. Within this strength-based approach, the family environment becomes more nurturing and less conflictual and both parents and children learn to self regulate their behavior.

Name: SwapAnHour
Location: Martin Pl, Sydney, New South Wales 2000, AU
Overview: Swap an hour (SwapAnHour) is a community of swappers with different skills and goods to exchange. You offer your skills to help a swapper and in return get free help for that time. You lend your goods to a swapper and in return borrow some goods for free. SwapAnHour doesn't discriminate by market value of skills or goods, an hour of gardening work is worth an hour of IT Support. Lending a mower is worth lending a surfboard.SwapAnHour’s currency is time fostering the spirit of community.Do you have a green thumb? Give some time of your gardening time and in return you can ask for an hour of help in something you might not be good at. You have a surfboard to lend in return you can borrow another good. There is also an option in the App for swappers to organise themselves into local communities if they only want to swap amongst themselves.SwapAnHour is an easy and secure that unlocks access to a community of swappers with different skills and goods. You ‘invest’ hours when you help or lend another swapper and in return you can ‘cash-in’ an hour of free time of other swappers on the network. Three easy steps. You create your task, you accept an offer and you build up your time. Swap the skills you have for the skill you need.Lend the goods you have for the good you want to borrow.

Name: Path 2 Change
Overview: Path 2 Change is a non-for-profit organisation that provides assistance to young people 15-24 years, who are homeless or experiencing homelessness, in the Newcastle, Lake Macquarie, Port Stephens and Hunter region.  For more than 30 years, Path 2 Change (formerly Newcastle Youth Accommodation Service) has provided secular, client-centred, and strength-based case management to young people with complex barriers who are homeless or at risk of homelessness. Our specialised support helps these young people to access education, training and employment opportunities and work towards a future of independence. Path 2 Change contributes to the Going Home Staying Home reform through collaborative case-management with Specialist Homelessness Services, and applies the ‘No Wrong Door’ approach to homelessness, in the Newcastle, Lake Macquarie, Lower Hunter and Port Stephens areas. Name: Pet Medical Crisis
Overview: In 2009, my Border Collie Jed was eight years old. He was playing with my 4 year old son, James, on the beach, when our world changed. While chasing seagulls, Jed ruptured several discs in his back. This started a series of major operations over three years, each costing many thousands of dollars.We were so fortunate to be able to afford his treatment and keep Jed with us. Without funds, the only option for Jed would have been euthanasia.This tragic experience inspired us to establish Pet Medical Crisis in 2010, supporting pensioners / disadvantaged owners to meet the high cost of veterinary care. Since then we have distributed over $450,000 to 500+ pets and continue to provide a much-needed service to our community.Jed relied on us to carry his back end in a special sling for 9 years.  He passed away on 17 December 2018 after providing us with untold joy, unconditional love and inspiration."​  Jennifer Hunt Founder PMCOur PurposePet Medical Crisis raises funds to assist pensioners / disadvantaged owners in necessitous circumstances with the costs medical intervention for companion pets in Victoria. The pet owner’s inability to fund the care would otherwise result in death or significantly impact quality of life.

Name: Stymie
Overview: Stymie is a confidential online messaging service that schools, universities, clubs, organisations and communities proactively use to support their students, staff, team, members and community to say something without fear. Stymie empowers people to reach out and get help for themselves or someone else, by enabling them to make an anonymous notification. Everyday... 1 in 4 students are bullied1 in 8 Australians end their life through suicideIn 2020 Stymie received approximately 66 000 anonymous notifications that changed, and saved lives. The notifications were for issues including; bullying, cyber bullying, sexual abuse, self harm, illegal activity, physical violence, family/domestic abuse, suicide ideation and self harm. Through our confidential online messaging service, we intentionally tackle social problems and in doing so we empower people to connect with their empathy and conscience so that they can, in a courageous way, enhance or change the culture of care in their school, club, community, university or organisation. We have built a robust, secure, yet surprisingly simple online messaging service. Our customers register for an annual subscription that enables their students, community, team, or members to use Stymie for free.We provide a comprehensive on boarding for all our clients.  We maintain weekly contact through socially relevant, engaging focus posts with our entire community to remind and reassure everyone that Stymie is available to anyone at anytime in your organization, club, community university or school.We have Stymie clients nationally and internationally. We operate in 200+ schools throughout Australia, New Zealand and the UAE.Our Founder and CEO, Rachel Downie was acknowledged for her work in 2020, being awarded the QLD Australian of The Year.Our vision is to create a culture of care for all Australians. We welcome the opportunity to work with you too.

Name: The Estate Concierge | Executor Assist | Deceased Estate Services
Overview: If you are someone who has recently become the Executor of a Will, whether you are a family member or staff member in a firm (Trustee company, law firm, Accountancy or Financial Planning), you have a big job ahead of you. In 2013 I was asked by a Trustee company to pack an estate for their client who didn't have any family who could do it. Once I was there I could see there was a simple process to follow to make sure everything is taken care of. I now pack and prepare deceased estates on a regular basis taking care of sentimental items, items for donation and sale, rubbish removal and then prepare the house for sale such as painters, cleaners, plumbers etc. It is my priority to ensure:~ Important documents such as Will's and Titles are found and given to the Executor.~ Items are sorted respectfully and sentimental items discussed with the Executor.~ Items are donated or recycled wherever possible to prevent landfill.~ Confidential items are destroyed appropriately.~ Environmentally aware services used where possible.~ Aid wherever possible to increase the value of the estate to benefit it's beneficiaries.~ Work with the Real Estate Agent and Executor for the best outcome for the property.An emotional journey for families, I can support them for parts of the process or I can complete it for them.

Fairhaven is also the largest provider of supported employment on the Central Coast. Name: The Fatherhood Project Incorporated

About the Fatherhood Project:
The Fatherhood Project is a not-for-profit organisation that aims for every father to be actively and positively engaged in their children’s lives.

What We Do:
The Fatherhood Project develops and delivers specialised education, support and mentoring programs for fathers that are uniquely ‘father friendly’, including expectant fathers’ group and Indigenous fathers’ circles.

We are also the founders of The Fatherhood Festival – a family and community event held on the Fathers’ Day weekend that celebrates fathers and the role of fatherhood.

Our Values:
We are dedicated to building healthy communities by enriching the lives of fathers, their children and families.

We support mothers and fathers as earners and carers.

About Our Programs:
Our programs have been developed in response to leading research in the areas of fatherhood, parenting, relationships and child development.

We use a community development and strengths-based approach to engaging with fathers and other agencies in addressing social issues and needs.

Name: Walk Of Life Training Inc (WOLTi)
Overview: WOLTi provides intensive life skills,  emotional education, employment training, education, case management and other supportive services to the community and specially to youth involved in youth justice, are homeless or experiencing abuse at home.  Our mission is to promote self sufficiency among the youth most in need.​​Walk Of Life Training inc. (WOLTi) focus is to assist disengaged youth who have broken up schooling, are in trouble with the law, are homeless or suffer from abuse in their homes. To access the youth most in need we mainly work at the Brisbane Youth Detention center (BYDC) at Wacol. We currently assist young people from the areas of Gold Coast, Logan, Western district, Scenic rim, Ipswich and Brisbane however and the Sunshine Coast.The training includes foundation and employability skills training, resume preparation, interview techniques, overcoming objections, work place visits, industry guest speakers, networking events with potential employers and employment related organisations, financial and time management, and one on one meetings throughout the program with each participant to discuss and make appropriate referrals to other community programs, training organisations and employer connections such as traineeships, work experience or job searching strategies.Organisational Goal:To creatively provide vulnerable Youth with the tools and knowledge they need to effectively plan and develop their future and connection to possible pathways.Organisational Objectives:Walk of Life Training Inc (WOLTi) is a Charitable and Not-For-Profit organisation established to  provide case management services to Disconnected Youth. Our aim is to interject at a very crucial point of a Young Person’s life therefore WOLTi runs their intervention and redirection program at Youth Detention centres and Youth Justice Centres working very closely with these departments with a focus to lower the re-offense rate of young detainees.*Caring for and supporting young people (YP) through free Youth-at-risk services which includes but not limited to; establishing emergency accommodation if when needed, delivery of food parcels, home visits, provision of fuel or transport cards for YP to get to important appointments, assist in name change process for transgender participants, referral to other community services or professional assistance such as counselling etc,*Operating a hostel/midway home for Young people being released from youth detention or young people who are homeless to provide relief and a better transition into the community in a holistic way through life skills training whilst at the hostel.Organisational Values:Integrity, Justice, Life Balance, Equality, and Self-sufficiency.

Name: Deaf Children Australia
Location: 597 St Kilda Road, Melbourne, VIC 3004, AU
Overview:
Deaf Children Australia employs over 60 staff and volunteers who, together with our Board of Directors, are united in their desire to remove barriers to the personal development and social inclusion faced by children and young people who are deaf or hard of hearing.

In achieving DCA’s vital work, our organisation, staff and volunteers uphold the following values:

Courage – We stand up for young people who are deaf and their families; and through innovation we strengthen their outcomes and hope for the future.
Respect – We are loyal to our history but respect the choice of individuals and the need for change.
Integrity – We are dependable in our service delivery and honour the commitments we make.
Teamwork – We embrace diverse opinions to build relationships that strengthen our capacity to achieve a common sector vision.
Resourcefulness – We are committed to delivering better value through efficient and effective systems and processes; and the use of resources entrusted to us.

We aim to provide children and young people who are deaf or hard of hearing and their families with the opportunities and skills to face life’s challenges and to celebrate their potential.

Deaf Children Australia provides a range of services to families with deaf and hard of hearing children. These services are developed in consultation with families.  

We work hard to promote opportunities for families and children to:

- access unbiased information,
- get connected with each other,
- participate in peer to peer support,
- access community, recreational and youth activities,
- engage counselling support , and to
- develop skills in advocacy, relationship building and influence

Deaf Children Australia strives to provide high quality services, and we welcome your feedback on all aspects of our service delivery.

Our aim is to constantly review and improve our ways of working with families.

Name: DEAI - Developmental Educators Australia Incorporated
Overview: Developmental Educators Australia Inc (DEAI) is the professional association representing the unique, diverse and dynamic profession of Developmental Education. Developmental Educators are multi-disciplinary disability specialists, having completed a disability specific tertiary degree. As allied health professionals, Developmental Educators, also known as DE’s, occupy roles in a variety of disability, human service, mental health, and educational settings, in the State and Federal Government, and non-government sectors. Developmental Educators aim to empower people with disabilities and their families to achieve social inclusion within the community, and to maximise their quality of life through the promotion of life skills development.The DEAI represents Developmental Educators Australia wide and welcomes membership from degree level trained Developmental Educators or disability professionals with comparable qualifications from across Australia. The vision of the DEAI is to promote the profession of Developmental Education within the human services.It is the DEAI’s mission to:*Represent Developmental Educators as their professional association.*Maintain common registration for all Developmental Educators.*Further a national association network in Australia for Developmental Educators.*Provide an accessible forum and networking / meeting place for Developmental Educators.*Promote the highest standard of professional conduct and practice of Developmental Educators.*Promote the continuing professional education of Developmental Educators.*Promote the profession Developmental Education to the general public.*Collaborate with Universities and agencies in the disability sector and wider human services for the promotion and exposure of Developmental Educators.

Name: Youth Off The Streets
Overview:

Since opening in 1991, Youth Off The Streets has grown from a single food van delivering meals to young homeless people on the streets of Kings Cross to a major youth specific agency offering a full continuum of care through delivery of a wide range of services. 

Our 25 services include crisis accommodation, alcohol and other drug services, counselling, accredited high schools, outreach, residential programs and a mentoring program. Volunteers support us every step of the way.

Overview:
Helping Refugees, Transforming Lives

The Australian Refugee Association (ARA) is a not-for-profit organisation and registered charity which was established in 1975. ARA seeks to enable refugees and asylum seekers, family and friends of refugees, community members, former refugees and migrants from similar backgrounds to settle in Australia with independence and dignity, and to develop and achieve their aspirations in life. ARA provides advice, assistance and advocacy in Settlement, Migration, Employment, Community Education and Policy Development.

Our vision is a South Australia where all refugees have access to the full range of appropriate settlement services, where refugees have strong supportive communities of their own cultural backgrounds, and where the general community is supportive of refugees and engaged with them.

Our vision is a South Australia where refugees are an integral part of a thriving and prosperous community.

Name: Interchange WA
Location: Unit 2, 15 Blackburn Street, MADDINGTON, WA 6109, AU
Overview:
We believe that there is a place for everyone in our community, and that no person should be excluded from enjoying a meaningful, rewarding life.

Since 1991, we’ve been providing personalised life experiences for people with disabilities who can’t maintain regular, prolonged employment or study.

People who qualify for social inclusion support receive funding from the Disability Services Commission to spend with the provider of their choice.

One of the reasons people choose Interchange is that our social inclusion programs aren’t picked from a set menu of activities – they’re individually designed to meet the aspirations of each client and their family.

Also, we’re dedicated to creating shared experiences with people in the general community, not in facilities hidden away from the world. This is how we build relationships, trust and acceptance, and help our clients become integral members of society.

Like peas in a pod, we’re all the same at heart. And we belong together.

Name: Eastern Domestic Violence Service (EDVOS)
Overview: EDVOS is a leading specialist family violence service in the eastern area of Victoria, Australia. Our work is focused across seven Local Government Areas including Boroondara, Manningham, Whitehorse, Monash, Knox, Maroondah and Yarra Ranges. Some of our training, education and primary prevention programs are national.EDVOS is predominantly funded to work with women and children. It is recognised that being female is the biggest risk factor for experiencing family violence. EDVOS acknowledges that family violence can take many forms such as intimate partner violence, child abuse, elder abuse, carer abuse, parental abuse and sibling abuse. Our specialist family violence response services are mostly directed towards women, including women from the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex (LGBTI) communities, children, pets and other animals, who are responding to any form of family violence.EDVOS is committed to assisting all people, regardless of ethnicity, race, religion, sexual orientation, gender identity, age and ability within our community and can also provide access to other family violence services that are most suitable to the individual’s unique needs and goals.Contact EDVOS P: (03) 9259 4200  E: edvos@edvos.org.au  W: edvos.org.au

Name: Eat Up Australia
Overview:
Too many primary school children go hungry, directly affecting their ability to concentrate, engage and enjoy school. Even those who are not readily identified as “disadvantaged” can go hungry.

Eat Up is an Australian not-for-profit that helps feed hungry kids. We partner with existing organisations to create a new service that provides healthy lunches for children at no cost.

This simple but powerful project is helping to ensure some of the most vulnerable children in our community are having their basic nutritional needs met.

Name: Multicultural Australia
Overview: For 21 years, Multicultural Australia (formerly Multicultural Development Australia) has been welcoming refugees, people seeking asylum, international students and other new arrivals to Queensland with the goal of creating a fairer, more prosperous society for all Queenslanders.We support more than 5,000 newly arrived Queenslanders every year, including refugees, international students, people seeking asylum and migrants.We help them to settle into their new lives, build connections in their communities, find work and study opportunities, learn new skills and feel at home.We also work with individuals, communities, business and government to help build a more welcoming Queensland through advocacy, cultural training and community events that bring people together, foster understanding and recognise the valuable contribution that new arrivals and migrants make to Queensland.

Name: Peter Tobin Funerals
Location: 1251 Doveton Street North, Ballarat, Victoria 3350, AU
Overview:
Peter Tobin Funerals is a family business which started in 1948 when Noel Tobin relocated his Maryborough funeral business to Ballarat, buying the firm of C. Wellington. In 1953, the business was consolidated at the location of the Star Dairy, 12 Dawson St South, with Noel's son Peter, joining him in 1957. Following Noel's retirement in 1971, Peter and his wife Faye moved into the Dawson St premises where they lived with their four children until 1984.

The name of Peter Tobin Funerals was adopted in 1982 to coincide with the fulfilment of Peter's dream of providing a beautiful venue where every person, their customs and beliefs are respected. The Doveton Park Funeral Centre was opened in 1984. Peter and Faye were joined by their daughter Paula in 1987.

Paula and her dedicated funeral staff proudly continue the family tradition of professional care to Ballarat families. Peter Tobin Funerals enviable reputation has been earned through its uncompromising standards of excellence in all aspects of funeral service.
Address_0: 1251 Doveton Street North, Ballarat, Victoria, 3350, AU

Our Brisbane based, Occupational Therapy for kids helps with everyday life activities such as making friends, exploring and trying new things, playing, being brave, being calm when things are hard, reading, writing, spelling, doing what they’re asked and motor skills. Name: Australian Dad's Network
Overview: Connecting with awesome like-minded men can be difficult. Especially if you’re living regionally, work a FIFO gig, moving frequently or just don’t have a group of mates you can really talk with. The Australian Dads Networks vision is to provide dads of Australia with a platform to connect with other dads and discuss all things that are relevant and required to be the best dad, man and husband you can be. With honesty and no judgement we can ask questions and get answers that will assist us in improving daily - in all areas of our lives. We have provided a space for men to discuss the hard-hitting and confronting topics that arise in our lives, topics that you have not or may not want to discuss with the current friend and family circle.So...you are now surrounded by like-minded, inspiring and epic mates from around the country to give you a helping hand. You can now get involved and share your wins and struggles, meet up locally for a coffee, beer or camping trip. You have the best support and resources available for dads in the country which will give you the power to be the best dads ever!Thanks for being a part of this group!  https://www.facebook.com/groups/australiandadsnetwork/about/

Name: JollyBabies Sleep Consultant
Overview: Hi, I’m Pragati Arora, a Paediatric Sleep Consultant helping parents to sleep their babies and Toddlers sleep better and longer with gentle and proven sleep methods. I have undergone a comprehensive certified training program and mentorship with Dana Obleman, best-selling author of ‘The Sleep Sense™ Program’ (and after 13 years in the business, one of the two top Sleep Trainers in the US). Dana’s methods have already helped over 100,000 parents and children, and I am so excited to get on board with the desired skills to help families sleep better.The current success rate for The Sleep Sense™ Program sits at 99%. You might have tried a number of books to follow, suggestions to follow and what worked for others, might not have worked to get your children to sleep, so why will the Sleep Sense strategy work? At JollyBabies, we will develop a gentle easy-to-follow, step-by-step customised sleep plan for your child taking account your own parenting styles and your child’s individual needs. No more sleepless nights, no more broken naps. Sleep is as important for a child as for adult and science has proved children who sleep better have better brain development and better IQ. I predominately focus on children aged from newborn to 5 years of age. I am located in the Eastern suburbs of Melbourne, Victoria and do provide in home consultations for Melbourne and around up to 50 km’s of area. Skype/Zoom consultations are also available in these areas, and worldwide. If you have an enquiry, please don’t hesitate to email me at pragati@jollybabies.com.au or call me on Phone: 0451 021 326.Check out my Offers and Seminars for more information.

Name: Puddle Jumpers Incorporated
Overview:
Puddle Jumpers is a non profit, non-government organisation committed to responding to the social development needs of society's most vulnerable children and young people; priority of our work is reserved for children who do not live with their birth parents.  We believe all kids matter, and deserve the right to engage in happy and fun experiences in their life.

Jump Over Puddles: We aim to empower children to recognise and express their individual abilities, interests, and talents, and to provide each child and young person with a transformative opportunity to grow and develop their own capacities and competencies. We aim to build resilience in kids to enable them to believe in themselves, to believe that anything is possible and help them ‘jump over puddles’ that they have in their own lives.

Jump in all the Puddles: We aim to enhance communiy cohesion, promote social inclusion, and encourage respect and tolerance for social diversity.  We aim to provide opportunities for self-challenge and development and facilitate opportunities for new learning in a fun and safe atmosphere. We aim to share the happiness and adventure of being children and young people, and simply encourage kids to be kids, to ‘jump in all the puddles’.

Name: Archdiocese of Sydney
Overview:
Yfoundations is the NSW non-governmental peak organisation for youth homelessness. We work to promoting the five foundations that support young people including wellbeing, connections, home & place, diversity and fairness. For over thirty years we have acted as a leader on youth homelessness policy and research having advised Government and other bodies on how to prevent, identify and support young people affected by homelessness.

We also provide important direct support services to young people facing crisis. We run a Yconnect line which offers the only statewide referrals for young people needing accommodation in NSW. Along with Yconnect we offer a range of health trainings for young people and workers.

At Yfoundations, our overriding principle is that young people matter and that childhood experiences and family background shouldn't inhibit anyone from achieving their dreams.

With offices in Kwinana, Mandurah,  and Armadale and satellite training offices in 8 locations north and south of the river,  BTG aims to develop and grow people and communities by providing caring and innovative lifelong learning opportunities and employment services. Name: Domestic Violence Action Centre INC
Overview: The Domestic Violence Action Centre INC (DVAC) is a not-for-profit organisation located in Ipswich and Toowoomba.Services are provided in the following communities and surrounding districts:Ipswich region and surrounds including Goodna, Springfield, Ripley and GoodnaToowoomba and Darling Downs regionLockyer Valley region including Gatton and LaidleySomerset region including Lowood, Esk and ToogoolawahPlace-based and electronic outreach to key satellites (Warwick, Stanthorpe, Dalby, Chinchilla, Goondiwindi, Oakey, Pittsworth) in the catchment.Since April 1994 DVAC has been committed to working with our communities towards the prevention and elimination of domestic and family violence.To this end, DVAC is actively involved in supporting women, young people and children who are experiencing or who have experienced domestic and family violence, supporting men who are actively committed to behaviour change as well as providing information and education to the communities at large.DVAC provides a range of services that include:Telephone information, referral, advocacy and support services to women and childrenCourt support for women in our three regional courtsCounselling services for women and childrenGroup work for women and childrenSafety upgrades for women and children wanting to stay in their homesSchools community education sessionsProviding professional training and resources to other service providers and stakeholdersCommunity development, education and awareness raising eventsA sexual assault service in Ipswich and Toowoomba regions.Group work and family support for young men (and their mothers) who are using violence against their mother and/or siblings.Men's Behaviour Change Program (Toowoomba)

Name: RizeUp Australia
Overview:
RizeUp Australia is a community driven organisation dedicated to supporting the brave families leaving domestic and family violence. We drive awareness of domestic and family violence in the media and, as a conduit between the domestic violence services and the community, we provide practical assistance to the families leaving violence behind with our programs. 

Founded by CEO Nicolle Edwards (Co-Founder/Director Assist A Sista), with Sonia Deakin, Director | Media/ Communications (M10 Communications, Director Assist A Sista) and Julie McCoy, Brand Manager (McCoyDesign, Brand Manager Assist A Sista) and an outstanding team of men and women from all walks of life, with Patrons Shelley Craft and Mia Freedman. We are better informed, connected and equipped to take a stronger stand against Domestic and Family Violence.

RIZEUP AT HOME: When families leave refuge they are given a barren property which we transform into a purposefully created home, specific to each family's individual needs, because we believe every family deserves a home free from domestic and family violence. homes@rizeup.com.au

RAPID RESPONSE: designed to meet the diverse needs and requirements of the families fleeing domestic violence within a confined time frame; Anything from food, blankets, urgent funds, etc. rapidresponse@rizeup.com.au

RIZE 4 LIAM: Because children deserve to live free from domestic and family violence, with the opportunity to reach their full potential. The costs associated with relocating children of school age can sometimes be immense; we assist these children to resettle into new schools, with uniforms, school books, bags, lunch boxes, water bottles, excursion fees, extracurricular activities, hair cuts; basically whatever it takes to raise their self esteem and help them to fit in. rize4liam@rizeup.com.au

Name: Simply Helping
Overview:
Simply Helping is a private provider of a suite of in-home care and support services to not only our elderly population, but also families and individuals living with a disability, clients of brokerage organisations and for those seeking services as a life-style choice.

Since 1998, we've steadily built our reputation for excellence and are expanding nationwide.

Our professional support extends to organisations, and both private or funded individuals.

Our teams of qualified and fully experienced carers are coordinated by our local managers responsible for service provision in their own regions.

This structure allows for greater involvement in support provision and much less bureaucracy in managing services. All our dedicated staff are trained, with ongoing support through mentoring and professional development programmes.

An active client and staff feedback system ensures continuous improvement and reinforces our client service commitment. Simply Helping applies insight to organisational, family and individual needs thus encouraging a professional, flexible and customised approach for each and every client.

Simply Helping also fully complies with the strict standards as set out by the Human Services Standards 2011, Certification National Standards for Disability Services 2013 Certification Department of Health and Human Services. The most recent surveillance audit took place on 26 and 27 September, 2016.

Our simple mission is to add value, meaning and dignity to the individual lives of others.

Name: Phoenix House Youth Services

Overview: For the past 30 years Phoenix House has provided early intervention and support services to the most challenged young people living in Northern Sydney and delivered life-changing outcomes.We provide a fully integrated, wrap around service model that places young people at the heart of what we do by building trusting relationships with them over time.Family breakdown, family violence, isolation, mental health and addiction issues do not discriminate and cut across the whole community – the Northern Sydney area is no different.The significant number of young people who need support remains a hidden concern, with the shortage of suitable services in the area a key issue. One in eight young people in the Northern Sydney area aged between 15 to 19 years is not in education or employment.We provide support programs to more than 500 young people each year to help them realise their dreams and aspirations, unlock their potential, achieve their goals and transform their lives.We work with young people and their families to improve family relationships. Positive family support has a significant impact on a young person’s success in life. Phoenix House provides a safe place that “holds” the individual in a contained and caring way allowing for their natural growth and development. Our role is to be there for them, to listen, be reliable, consistent and genuine, honest and open. We challenge their lack of self-belief and support them to develop a strength-based view of themselves and build a positive outlook for their future.

Name: Gunawirra
Location: 19a Quirk Street (Cnr Quirk & Gordon St), Rozelle, NSW 2039, AU
Overview:
Gunawirra is a not-for-profit PBI organisation made up of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal professionals and specialists working side by side for Aboriginal young women, men and their children from the ages of 0 to 5.

The Aboriginal people are fundamental to the Australian nation. They provide us with rich gifts of an ancient spiritual culture with links to the earth and country. Their power to survive is born out of a remarkable resilience through an interwoven sense of community that defies all efforts to destroy it. We know that a space to grow with a mother freed from anxiety is the best and most nurturing place for any child of any culture or race to develop and that secure attachment and bonding is the essential core from which later adult health is born.

In a spirit of empathic understanding and reconciliation, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal professionals from Gunawirra, each supporting the other, work in companionship and harmony seeking a better and fuller life for Aboriginal and other marginalised peoples in Australia.

The primary role of Gunawirra is the design of unique, innovative and transformational programs. These models of excellence are fully evaluated to empower young Aboriginal parents with children aged 0-5 years to intervene in their own lives, breaking the life cycle of suffering caused by loss of country, community, culture and family.

Name: Therapy Connect
Overview: 'Therapy Anywhere Anytime'Therapy Connect provides flexible, person-centred allied health supports via telepractice for people who experience disability or delay in development that affects their participation at home, in the community, in childcare, education or the workplace. Our services include speech and occupational therapy, psychology, dietetics and physiotherapy, all delivered online. The individuals we work with present with challenges in the areas of learning, behaviour, communication, social interaction, mobility and motor skills, performing daily tasks and nutrition. Therapy Connect works with people across Australia and Asia who live in rural, regional and remote areas or experience difficulty accessing sufficient therapy support to meet their needs. This may be due to geographic location, large local waiting lists or a lack of local service providers. Therapy Connect links allied health clinicians to families and their support networks via telecommunications technology, such as web-based videoconferencing, an innovative approach that has proven successful in providing timely access to highly experienced allied health practitioners for people isolated from services.

Name: The Wealth Tutor
Overview:
The Wealth Tutor is a financial and life coaching practice whose vision is to assist others to reach their full potential. Whether it be short, medium or long-term goals, The Wealth Tutor can help you break past those barriers that seem to prevent you from achieving your goals.

The Wealth Tutor specialises in getting out of debt, teaching you to manage your money – regardless of how much you have, changing ‘bad spending habits’ to ‘good saving habits’, securing a great financial future – and getting out of the rat-race early!

To be truly successful and satisfied you need to have balance in all areas of your life. Because money isn’t just a dollar figure, money equates to choice, The Wealth Tutor also offers life coaching. Do you know what you will do, what your life will be like when you have the choice? Here at The Wealth Tutor, we will help you figure out what you want and how to get it!

How can The Wealth Tutor help you get there? Because founder and coach, Kristina Plimer, has.

In just over ten years, Kristina has gone from owing over $30k to a bank at 19% interest with little to no idea about how to properly manage her finances, to being well on track to an early retirement and securing financial freedom. And now, Kristina has achieved that elusive goal of not only true work/life balance, but life/life balance!

Name: Kindred Life
Overview: At Kindred Life, we sit down with you and hold your hand as you navigate the confusing - and often overwhelming - process of getting your affairs in order. We help you write down your legacy for generations of your loved ones to enjoy and plan a 'party of a lifetime'​ to celebrate your life in the way you deserve.In three easy steps, the Kindred Life team will simplify the process to help you plan ahead, record your life story and create a unique celebration of a lifetime in your honour.STEP 1: PREPARE AHEAD. Get your affairs in order with a Kindred Life Plan. We help you to record your wishes, organise your important documentation and prepare your life plan. We give you the gift of peace of mind, knowing that everything is prepared for when the time comes.STEP 2: RECORD YOUR STORY. A life lived is a life worthy of sharing with a Kindred Life Story. We create your personal time-capsule, recording all the stories and life lessons you have learned in a beautiful heirloom book. We capture the details of your life story with stunning words and images, preserving all the highlights and adventures, creating a cherished legacy for generations to come.STEP 3: RAISE A GLASS! Celebrate your life with a Kindred Life Event. Whether it is a lavish funeral celebration or an intimate memorial gathering, we plan and deliver a celebration of your life that is a perfect reflection of your unique personality and style. On the beach, at the park, or perhaps the family home. It's your day - why not celebrate it your way?Whether as our guest or as a new member of our team, how can we help you on your Kindred Life journey?

Name: Hushhh Hub Ltd
Overview: Hushhh Hub is a not for profit organisation dedicated to opening a house where parents can come with their babies and get some sleep! Sounds strange, we know, but with so many parents feeling unsupported and isolated; we need to step up and provide a solution.Parents of new babies with no or limited family support are exhausted and suffering.Up to 74% of parents don't seek help until they reach the point where they can't cope.1 in 7 mothers and 1 in 10 fathers experience postnatal anxiety or depression.Struggling parents = struggling families = struggling communities.There is no respite for new parents available at this time – this affects each of us.With immigration, FIFO families, single parent families and the lack of proximity to extended families, the extent of the isolation and lack of support it often hidden behind closed doors.Hushhh Hub will offer a safety net, respite for exhausted parents in those long sleepless days. Hushhh Hub will offer early intervention before depression and helplessness set in.  We believe a drop of ‘prevention’ is worth a bucket of ‘cure’.We are unique in our concept where we are not designed to teach parenting skills, we are providing the practical and emotional support to the parents so they can have the focus and energy to enjoy being a parent. Hushhh Hub believe in collaboration with existing parenting services such as health professionals, family support services and external agencies to encourage a holistic approach for the best outcome.Hushhh Hub will have a far-reaching social impact because by supporting the parents we are increasing their mental wellness, which will affect their productivity in the workforce and community, and baby will be able to thrive. Hushhh Hub rely on grants and donations to assist as many families as we can. If you would like to become part of the movement to build stronger family units in  Perth WA in a very unique way we look forward to hearing from you.

Name: Chipmunks Childcare
Location: 18 Mariana Crescent, Lethbridge Park, Sydney, NSW 2770, AU
Overview:
At Chipmunks Childcare, we believe children learn best in an environment that encourages exploration, provides nurturing supportive relationships, adapts to each individual child’s learning styles and needs, and offers many opportunities for play. We are committed to providing the highest quality child care and early learning education solutions.

What makes us different?

1) Emphasis on natural surroundings
We believe young children need to be engaged with natural surroundings rather than modern synthetic environments.

2) Education
We do not believe in simple child-minding and believe the path to learning commences from birth. We have comprehensive educational programs targeted to age and development skills.

3) Child psychology
Early childhood development requires caretakers to balance eagerness for pursuing adventure, creativity and self-expression with the development of responsibility. We aspire to set the standard in implementing modern understandings of child psychology in all our centres.

4) Care
All our staff provide a fun and loving environment where children want to attend our service.

Name: Allsorts Organising
Overview: Established in 2012, Allsorts Organising are decluttering and organising specialists based in Canberra, Australia.  Our Vision is to reclaim space and time and simplify the lives of individuals in Canberra and surrounding areas.Our clients, including NDIS participants (self-managed and plan-managed) and those from the community sector, come to us because we understand the challenges of disorganisation.  Our aim is to empower individuals to create an environment that is safe, healthy and comforting.  We do so with professionalism, patience and integrity and without judgment.  If you are time-poor, disorganised, overwhelmed by clutter or daily obligations, trying to find work-life balance, or may even be dealing with a crisis or mental health issue such as grief, depression, anxiety or hoarding behaviours, we can assist.  We are not counsellors or psychologists but we are Canberra’s most experienced and qualified Professional Organisers with extensive experience and formal training, including specialist training for working with individuals who struggle with hoarding disorder.  At the core of our service, is a people-centric and project-based methodology.  We work in partnership with individuals, couples, families and organisations to achieve results, whilst focusing on safety, functionality and sustainability for all residents of the home.  There is no one-size-fits-all approach.  We bring a full “tool kit” of techniques, strategies and tools, together with ears to listen, creative and thoughtful minds to guide, arms and legs to help shift the physical, and compassionate and caring hearts to hold space for you.Allsorts Organising are fully insured with Public Liability, Professional Indemnity and Workers Compensation insurances. All team members hold current National Police Checks and ACT Working with Vulnerable People registrations at a minimum.You are in good hands with the team from Allsorts Organising.

Name: Happily Gifted
Overview:
Every parent wants to see their child happy, but unfortunately that's not always the case. When your child is gifted, people often think that both you and your child are really lucky and that life must be easy raising this child. Gifted children do indeed have a lot of great qualities: they are passionate, quick thinkers, curious and like to take big steps towards a result instead of doing things in small steps, just to mention a few. 

Unfortunately, it isn't always as easy as it seems. Gifted children often feel like they don't fit in, they can be very unhappy at school and face a variety of other difficulties related to being gifted. 

Happily Gifted's goal is to offer a place where gifted children can be seen for what they really are: creative, bright, inquisitive, amazing! By meeting likeminded peers, reviving the desire to learn and working on difficulties like performance anxiety or a fixed mindset, gifted children can be helped to become happier people. 

Giving gifted children room for their own development, in school, at home and in society, creates beautiful opportunities for these children and the people around them. Happily Gifted creates an environment where they can fully develop emotionally and socially. From this base the children can enter relationships with other (gifted) children. This allows gifted children to develop into happy children who dare to use their skills at home, at school and in society. 

Happily Gifted also supports parents, teachers and other professionals who require help coaching gifted children. With Tessa's background in education, extensive theoretical knowledge about giftedness and broad experience in working with these children, Happily Gifted is able to offer tailored advice and assistance.

Please contact Tessa Hamstra if you have any questions, comments or if you would like to get some more information:
58 Jamieson Street, Bulimba (Brisbane suburb), QLD, Australia
+61 4 3236 3551
happilygifted@outlook.com

Name: Hearts in Union, Rugby Foundation Australia
Overview:
Hearts in Union is a charity that is all about assisting those players who have suffered severe spinal injury during a rugby game.

Rugby is a wonderful game played by people who enjoy the spirit of “mateship” and “fair play”. Unfortunately, some players through a freak accident have their lives changed forever. Spinal injuries place a physical, emotional and financial strain on the player for the rest of their lives.

We aim to ensure those severely injured players who are suffering financial hardship receive the best possible support throughout their lives. 

Thank you to our generous sponsors & supporters

Name: Maria Paterakis - Future Proofing Counsellor
Overview: Are you denying you are in your Midlife?  Is it because we are experiencing a different midlife to our parents?By their late 40’s, many of our parents were empty-nesters. Today we have small children, teenagers or young adults who still live at home. For some, there are grandchildren and second round children at the same time. Some have never partnered or had children, which is more likely for women. We worry about our aging parents and are often have responsibility for their care and needs. A high proportion of us have experienced divorce, and we have some of the highest levels of debt. Ladies, we have the added pressure of perimenopausal hormonal changes.  We know our superannuation won’t be enough and the safety net of a pension may not be there. Meanwhile, the volatility of the job market and pending ageism is also on our minds, especially as we may need to work longer than the generation before us.I am Maria Paterakis, The Midlife  Counsellor.  With graduate qualifications in Psychology, and over 25  years of experience supporting people, there isn't, much I haven't  heard.I know how busy you are.  I understand the stress and  pressure on you.  I know what keeps you up at night, where your  frustrations are, and that there is silent rage inside of you that you  fear will soon be unleashed.  I provide you with the support you need  for your life today, not only to manage, but to thrive.....So you have  Clarity and Confidence for Today and Tomorrow.

Overview: We are a family run business, first established in 1974.We pride ourselves on understanding the needs of our community and providing the highest quality education and care to children and their family groups.We draw perspective and insight from many different disciplines, philosophers and pedagogy, from Australia and overseas. Our philosophy and practice is thus informed by that of the Municipal Schools of Reggio Emilia, Rudolf Steiner and Maria Montessori, as well as our own observations and interactions.Our LogoOur logo was developed using the research developed by one child Ruby, 3.6 years, over a number of months. Following her emerging interest in horses, Ruby spent time researching at the library. Ruby’s subsequent drawings demonstrate the benefits of research and artistic process, giving her the ability to express her understanding, with the Studio Coordinators encouragement and support.The four horses illustrate Ruby’s growing knowledge of a horse’s movement, bone structure and muscles. Through these images Ruby shows her emerging understanding and shares her learning with her peers.

Name: Shine Inspire Achieve Belong Inc
Overview:
At SHINE we have accepted the challenge to bring on the learning revolution and have developed a one of a kind program that is ground breaking, award winning and has demonstrated unprecedented outcomes in changing the lives of early adolescent girls.

SHINE Mission
‘Support, educate and empower young girls with life skills and emotional tools that help to place their future in their hands. 

The program was started in 2010 by founder Mandy Jolley at John Willcock College Geraldton with a strategic focus on improved education, retention, and attendance of the at risk13 to 15-year-old Aboriginal girls in the education system.  

The life skills and values based training SHINE has created is delivered in a fully purpose built hairdressing salon.  Through the structured and nurturing Shine environment, the young women’s life skills and values are developed; having a great effect on fundamental skills such as accountability, responsibility, trust, connection, and employability. 

The program has outstanding documented results in improved attendance, behaviour and academic achievement.The SHINE model transcends language, culture, socioeconomic and geographical parameters to create an environment that is safe, open and most important, a space where girls become accountable and responsible for their actions and behaviour.

In 2016, SHINE expanded the program to Geraldton Senior College that works exclusively with the senior students in Years 10 - 12.  Other highschools in WA have expressed interest in the program.

SHINE is based on the belief that true generational change starts with the empowerment of young girls.

Name: The Learning Clinic Pty Ltd
Overview:
The Learning Clinic (formerly the Australian office of one of the world's leading organisations in Autism and ABA services, the Center for Autism and Related Disorders) has a long history of ABA services in Australia. We are one of Sydney's oldest and most experienced ABA service providers, treating children with autism since January 1997. Over the last 16 years, we have treated hundreds of children, adolescents and adults with Autism, Asperger's, learning difficulties, speech delays, challenging behaviours, global delay and a variety of other diagnoses and difficulties. 

In 2013, Karen Wong and Aarathy Kumar took over full ownership and The Learning Clinic was founded with an emphasis on providing local services for local families. We still pride ourselves in delivering state of the art services based on internationally recognised best practices, research and gold standard training; however we wanted to focus our administration and policies on local practices, funding concerns and families and being able to help the wider community.

Name: Ability Links NSW
Location: 956 Hunter St , Unit 1a , Newcastle West, NSW 2302, AU
Overview: Ability Links NSW - Linking people and communities with opportunities.How does Ability Links NSW work?Ability Links NSW Coordinators, known as Linkers, work closely with people with disability, their families and carers to support them to fulfil their goals, hopes and dreams.Whether your goal is to take part in sport, education, volunteering, or other activities, you remain at the centre of decision making about how you want to lead your life.Linkers have strong local knowledge and work alongside communities, supporting them to be welcoming and inclusive.Linkers can help you to:find ways to be a part of your local communityset goals and plan for your futurebuild confidence to achieve your dreamsdevelop your existing support networks and create new networks.There are a number of providers around the state who can put you in touch with a Linker. Linking with everyoneLinkers work with all people and communities, including people from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds, and Aboriginal communities. Linkers will support you to be part of your local and extended community.You can contact a Linker whenever you need to, and in a way that suits you.The role of a Linker is to provide short-term support to achieve a particular outcome.Linkers can be contacted again in the future if another goal is identified or further support or information is needed.Ability Links NSW also recognises that children with disability and their families have specific and unique needs around the time of diagnosis. Early Linkers support families to use informal and community supports.  We also understand that Aboriginal people require flexible and culturally appropriate supports. Ability Links NSW offers the choice of an Aboriginal Linker if that's right for you.Who can use Ability Links NSW?Ability Links NSW is for:people with disability aged 0 to 64 yearscarers and families of people with disability.Individual, clubs, groups and businesses can also access Ability Links NSW for information and support on inclusion of people with disability.There is no formal assessment process or referral that you need to meet in order to use Ability Links NSW.How much does it cost?Nothing. Ability Links is a free program.

The first contact is often from  worried parents anxious for information after having  been told that the baby they are expecting  has spina bifida.

Veritas House is a community-based, not-for-profit incorporated organisation and a registered charity that provides a range of flexible services to children, young people, and families in Central Western NSW.

Name: National PEKE Centre
Overview: Comprehensive support across the lifespan from diagnosis to strength based therapies and family supports – Specialising in Autism, ADHD, Anxiety, Sensory Challenges, and Regulation Support.The National PEKE Centre first started as a dream by company founders Rebecca Perkins and Christina Keeble. Who as parents of neurodivergent children as well as themselves being neurodiverse adults wished for a different way for services and therapies to be offered.They were tired of dealing with clinicians and therapists who didn’t talk to each other. Tired of traveling to different places to access therapies and supports. And most of all were saddened to keep hearing from parents and individuals who simply didn’t know what to do or what therapies to access for their child after diagnosis.At the National PEKE Centre Rebecca and Christina’s dream became a reality. All clinicians work as a team with the family or individual to create the best possible success, and everything from diagnosis to strength based therapies and family supports are all under one roof.Best of all you will never need to feel confused about where to go or what to do next. Our in house Support Specialist is available for appointments to help you with all your enquiries. From how to deal with certain behaviours to what funding is available to you, information regarding school to NDIS questions. Or just wanting to understand more about your child’s needs. Your Support Specialist is there to help, via in person or zoom appointments.

Name: The Queen's Fund
Overview: The Queen’s Fund provides emergency funding to single Victorian women in crisis in the form of financial grants up to $350.  The assistance can help prevent homelessness, enable a woman to escape domestic violence, provide education or training for a woman and/or her children, pay essential medical bills or provide crucial breathing space so a woman can get her life back on track.We work with social workers from 240 welfare agencies across Victoria who are in the best position to determine how to help the woman in need. They continue to support her after our emergency relief has been provided.Founded in 1887, we are one of Victoria’s oldest charities. Our committee is unpaid and we have very low overheads.  Any overheads we do have are covered by a historical bequest. Overview: Association for Children with a Disability (ACD) is Victoria’s leading support service for families with a child with any type of disability or developmental delay.ACD exists to improve the lives of children with a disability and their families, by empowering them to secure the best possible outcomes for their children. We do this by providing accurate information about their rights and entitlement to services and supports and by offering advocacy advice when issues arise.Our services include a free telephone support line, free workshops which cover topics such as how to access disability services, education planning for children with a disability, and how to deal with educational transitions and milestones. Name: Holyoake
Overview:
Founded in 1975, Holyoake is a leading provider of alcohol and drug treatment services. Our purpose is to bring lasting change to lives and communities through a holistic, non-judgemental approach.
We have constantly responded to changing needs of society by developing a range of programs for people of all ages and circumstances. This includes individual as well as group counselling for people who are affected either directly or indirectly by substance misuse.
Holyoake is committed to social enterprise and innovation to achieve better social outcomes while ensuring financial sustainability. We offer DRUMBEAT – an evidence-based, award-winning therapeutic program which is facilitated in Australia, New Zealand and the USA. We also offer Wellbeing@Work, a suite of programs for corporate organisations. These engaging and relevant programs focus on stress and coping mechanisms while promoting self-responsibility, wellbeing and risk management.
Holyoake is governed by a Board of eminent professionals who are dedicated to the organisation’s vision and mission. The Board includes Ms Marylyn New (Chair), Mr Gary Steinepreis (Treasurer), Mr Ian Oldfield, Chief Justice Hon. Wayne Martin, Mr Kevin Campbell, and Ms Angie Paskevicius (CEO).

Name: International China Concern
Overview:
International China Concern is a Christian development organisation bringing love, hope and opportunity to China’s abandoned and disabled.  Founded in 1993 by David Gotts, International China Concern exists to help the disadvantaged live life to the full and to their God-given potential.

The Chinese government is committed to developing a comprehensive social welfare system. International China Concern works in partnership with the government to help make that aim a reality.

We believe every child is precious and has the right to be loved, to have hope for the future and the opportunity to realise their dreams.

Name: HYPA
Overview:
HYPA, standing for Helping Young People Achieve, provides a wide range of support to young people to find and harness their talent for a positive future.  It has supported many thousands of young people since its inception in September 1958, helping them to access and maintain safe and appropriate accommodation, to reconnect with family, school, employment and the community.

Many of the young people we support have experienced trauma in their lives and need extensive support. We recognize that despite their often chaotic life circumstances, the young people who come to HYPA are incredibly resilient. We believe every young person we help has the strength and capacity to bring about positive change and build a future beyond their present expectations.

Our work is focused on four areas which align to the priorities of a young person's life: Home, Wellbeing, Learning and Working.

HYPA is a division of SYC, a not-for-profit organisation centred on employment, training and youth services.  With a core purpose to positively affect the lives of people in need, last year SYC helped more than 61,000 people in the areas of Home, Wellbeing, Learning and Working.

Name: National Centre for Childhood Grief
Location: 14 Hollis Avenue, Denistone East, NSW 2112, AU
Overview: The National Centre for Childhood Grief (NCCG) is dedicated to helping bereaved children and their families rebuild their lives, by teaching them how to live with their grief. The Centre was established in 1994 by founders Mal and Dianne McKissock, internationally recognised experts in the field of child bereavement and grief counselling.  Both Mal and Dianne have been honoured with an OAM for their important contribution.We are Australia’s only provider of free and unlimited grief counselling for bereaved children aged 3 -18 years.  The McKissock therapeutic model, developed and used at the Centre, represents best practice when working with bereaved people.  We operate from ‘A Friend’s Place’, our dedicated bereavement care centre in Denistone East, Sydney.  We offer a range of programs nationally, supporting children, families, adults and those who work with the bereaved.  We have an experienced team of specialist bereavement counsellors and trained volunteer support workers, led by our Clinical Director, Dr Elizabeth Mann, ensuring the effective delivery of our services.One in 20 of Australian children have experienced the death of one or both parents.  We know this has a profound and lifelong impact on children.  We know that our services contribute greatly to providing a child with the opportunity and resources to go on and live a full and meaningful life.

Name: Triple P Australia
Location: 11a Market Street North, Indooroopilly, Brisbane, Queensland 4068, AU
Overview: The Triple P – Positive Parenting Program was originally developed in Australia and is now delivered around the world. TRIPLE P IN AUSTRALIAThousands of individuals and agencies deliver various Triple P programs to families as part of government-funded initiatives, health and community service programs, school and early childhood education family support, and/or charitable and NGO family support systems.As the importance of providing a safe, secure and developmentally appropriate early childhood environment becomes more obvious, more Australian policy makers are wanting to take a pro-active approach to issues such as substance abuse, suicide, and child protection, with positive interventions aimed at giving all children a healthy start in life.Currently in Queensland, there is a state-wide population rollout of free Triple P programs to all parents and carers of children under 16. This includes Triple P interventions from low-intensity large-group seminars through to individual high-intensity support programs, online versions of Triple P and Teen Triple P, Group Triple P with an Indigenous focus. Our implementation partners include school counsellors, Queensland Health nurses, and charities. Two dedicated Indigenous Implementation Consultants (ICs) work with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and organisations to help ensure culturally safe delivery of the program.Triple P programs are also used extensively in WA, NSW, and Victoria. We also support partner organisations to improve their understanding of the program’s alignment with attachment theory and trauma-informed care as the program is used in a broad range of settings. Our complete system of flexible, evidence-based interventions (including e-mental health options, low literacy adaptations, programs for parents and carers of children with a disability, and more) helps providers and services to create positive change by improving parenting skills, knowledge and confidence.

Name: Reframing Autism
Overview: Reframing Autism’s vision is to create a world in which the Autistic community is supported by its families and allies to achieve genuine acceptance, inclusion, and active citizenship, and in which Autistic culture and identity are celebrated and nurtured.Reframing Autism is a company run by and for Autistic people, and for their families and allies. Reframing Autism combines capacity-building and leadership development with education, research, resource development, mentoring, and support to strengthen the Autistic community and to bring together the Autistic and autism communities for social change.   Reframing Autism is an innovative group in which Autistic people, and non-autistic families and allies of the Autistic community, come together to understand Autism and neurodiversity. We promote equity and acceptance. Our vision and goals align with the Australian National Disability Strategy 2010−2020 and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.  Working within the neurodiversity movement, Reframing Autism offers both support and practical education. It fosters environments in which Autistic individuals can live authentically, , and it builds the capacity of families, allies and Autistic people themselves to be leaders and change agents for the Autistic community.  Reframing Autism nurtures a united community which bridges the existing divisive gap between the Autistic community (those identified or who self-identify as Autistic) and the autism community (the broader non-autistic community with vested interest in or connection to Autism).  Reframing Autism is a Health Promotion Charity, and its activities are intended to impact positively the current mental health profile of the Autistic community that is linked to lifelong discrimination, stigmatisation, exclusion and concealment.

Name: HomeGround Services
Overview:
HomeGround Services merged with Hanover Welfare Services in 2015 to from Launch Housing. This account is no longer monitored. Find out more:
http://www.launchhousing.org.au/
https://www.linkedin.com/company/launch-housing 

HomeGround’s vision is to end homelessness in Melbourne. Our mission is to get people housed and to keep people housed. 

We do this by providing housing and support services across Melbourne, developing innovative housing models, advocating for systems change and researching the causes and solutions to homelessness. We are independent, secular and not-for-profit.

We value:

People - People are at the centre of everything we do. We think about the impact our decisions have on each other, our clients and everyone we work with. We are compassionate and we listen.

Respect - Respect is appreciating what we value and honouring who we are. We treat others the way we want to be treated and earn respect through this mutual understanding.

Dignity - Everyone has the right to realise their potential and recognise their self worth. HomeGround’s mission and practices value the dignity of all individuals.

Choice - Each person has the right to make informed and empowered personal choices without interference. Regardless of whether or not we agree with the choices people make, we will respect their right to choose.

Diversity - Drawing on the power of people’s differences is of equal value as gaining strength from the similarities. We respect our differences and learn from them.

Find out more at:

www.homeground.org.au 
www.facebook.com/homegroundservices 
www.youtube.com/homegroundservices

Name: Hannah's House

Overview: The Children’s Hospice Association (INC) trading as Hannah’s House, was founded by Martin Watson and Jacky Vigurs, parents of Hannah Watson who was born with a rare syndrome called Opitz Trigonocephaly. She had profound intellectual and physical disabilities and complex medical needs, that required around the clock care.Hannah was not expected to live beyond her first birthday. She passed away in 2010 aged 19 with Jacky and Martin her lifelong carers.Caring for a child with complex needs requires commitment 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The challenges of providing ongoing care with little or no support, has been found to lead to social isolation, sleep deprivation, stress, fatigue and anxiety for parents. These stressors can soon impact negatively on home, work and social life and place the family under great strain.Hannah’s House focuses on quality of life for the child and support for the whole family. Our packages support children with life-limiting conditions and complex needs and their families, from diagnosis to recovery; or palliative care and bereavement and beyond.Charitable StatusThe Children’s Hospice Association (INC) is a registered public benevolent institution (PBI) and charity with the Australian Charities and Not-for-profits Commission (ACNC) and are an endorsed deductible gift recipient (DGR) by the Australian Tax Office. Donations made to Hannah’s House of $2 and over are tax deductible.

Name: Assessments Australia

Name: My Supports
Overview: My Supports was founded in 2015 by people with a disability and families.The founders saw the NDIS as an opportunity for people with a disability to play a greater role in designing and delivering services. They believe this will lead to better, more innovative services, due to the experiences and insights people with the lived experience can bring.My Supports is a fully registered and audited NDIS Service Provider operating in five states – NSW, VIC, QLD, WA & SA. My Supports is one of the most successful new providers in the NDIS. My Supports supports over 1,500 clients.My Supports is unique in three ways:(1) We are a Disabled People Organisation and Families Organisation (DPO/FO*)- We bring the lived experience of disability into services - 50% of our staff to have the lived experience of disability- The NDIS marketplace will be more diverse and end-user focused if people with a disability and their families are helping shape services. - NDIA Definition DPO/FOs:"Are led and controlled by people with a disability or their families with a minimum membership of 50% of people with a disability or their families making up the board, staff, volunteers and members."​.(2) We work via small, local Neighbourhood Teams- Support via local people bringing local connections and contacts- Flexible, local, your choice of support worker – but with full safeguarding and supervision(3) Innovation- We are pioneering in-community support options, as an alternative to support in an institutional environment- Support to live in-community for all abilities, including people with complex and high needs- In-community housing-support options – such as NDIA SIL innovation and NDIA ILOsMy Supports can be contacted via www.mysupports.com.au or info@mysupports.com.au.

Name: CareNow
Overview: CareNow is an organisation that works to help support and empower children who have special needs to thrive and reach their full potential.
